author: ovid

0.0: For mighty wars I thought to tune my lute,
0.1: And make my measures to my subject suit.
0.2: Six feet for ev'ry verse the muse design'd,
0.3: But Cupid laughing, when he saw my mind,
0.4: From ev'ry second verse a foot purloin'd.
0.5: "Who gave thee, boy, this arbitrary sway,
0.6: On subjects, not thy own, commands to lay,
0.7: Who Phoebus only, and his laws obey ?
0.8: 'Tis more absurd, than if the queen of love
0.9: Should in Minerva's arms to battle move;
0.10: Or manly Pallas from that queen should take
0.11: Her torch, and o'er the dying lover shake.
0.12: In fields as well may Cynthia sow the corn,
0.13:
Or Ceres wind in woods the
						bugle-horn;
0.14: As well may Phoebus quit the trembling string,
0.15: For sword and shield; and Mars may learn to sing.
0.16: Already thy dominions are too large;
0.17: Be not ambitious of a foreign charge.
0.18: If thou wilt reign o'er all, and ev'ry where,
0.19: The god of music for his harp may fear.
0.20: Thus when with soaring wings I seek renown,
0.21: Thou pluck'st my pinions, and I flutter down.
0.22: Could I on such mean thoughts my muse employ,
0.23: I want a mistress, or a blooming boy."
0.24: Thus I complain'd; his bow the stripling bent,
0.25: And chose an arrow fit for his intent.
0.26: The shaft his purpose fatally pursues;
0.27: " Now, poet, there's a subject for thy muse,"
0.28: He said: (too well, alas, he knows his trade,)
0.29: For in my breast a mortal wound he made.
0.30: Far hence ye proud Hexameters remove,
0.31: My verse is pac'd, and tramell'd into love.
0.32: With myrtle wreaths my thoughtful brows enclose,
0.33: While in unequal verse I sing my woes.

1.0: Ah me! why am I so uneasy grown?
1.1: Ah! why so restless on my bed of down?
1.2: Why do I wish to sleep, but wish in vain?
1.3: Why am I all the tedious night in pain?
1.4: What cause is this, that ease, that rest denies?
1.5: And why my words break forth in gentle sighs?
1.6: Sure I should know if love had fix'd his dart;
1.7: Or creeps he softly in with treacherous art,
1.8: And then grows tyrant, there and wounds the heart?
1.9: 'Tis so, the shaft sticks deep, and galls my breast;
1.10: 'Tis tyrant love, that robs my thoughts of rest!
1.11: Well, shall I tamely yield, or must I fight?
1.12: I'll yield; 'tis patience makes a burden light:
1.13: A shaken torch grows fierce, and sparks arise;
1.14: But, if unmov'd, the fire looks pale and dies.
1.15: The hard-mouth'd horse smarts for his fierce disdain
1.16: The gentle's ridden with a looser rein.
1.17: Love smooths the gentle, but the fierce reclaims;
1.18: He fires their breasts, and fills their souls with flames.
1.19: I yield; great Love, my former crimes forgive,
1.20: Forget my rebel thoughts, and let me live;
1.21: No need of force: I willingly obey,
1.22: And now unarm'd, shall prove no glorious prey.
1.23: Go take thy mother's doves, thy myrtle crown,
1.24: And for thy chariot, Mars shall lend his own;
1.25: There thou shalt sit in thy triumphant pride,
1.26: And, whilst glad shouts resound on ev'ry side,
1.27: Thy gentle hands thy mother's doves shall guide.
1.28: And there to make thy glorious pomp and state,
1.29: A train of sighing youths, and maids shall wait,
1.30: Yet none complain of an unhappy fate.
1.31: There newly conquer'd I, still fresh my wound,
1.32: Will march along, my hands with myrtle bound;
1.33: There modesty, with veils thrown o'er her face,
1.34: Now doubly blushing at her own disgrace;
1.35: There sober thoughts, and whatso'er disdains
1.36: Love's rules, shall feel his power, and bear his chains:
1.37: Then all shall fear, all bow, yet all rejoice;
1.39: Thy constant guards, soft fancy, hope and fear,
1.40: Anger, and soft caresses shall be there:
1.41: By these strong guards are men and gods o'erthrown;
1.42: These conquer for thee, Love, and these alone,
1.43: Thy mother, from the sky thy pomp shall grace,
1.44: And scatter sweetest roses in thy face:
1.45: There glorious Love shall ride, profusely dress'd
1.46: With all the richest jewels of the east:
1.47: Rich gems thy quiver, and thy wheels infold,
1.48: And hide the poorness of the baser gold.
1.49: Then thou shalt conquer many, then.thy darts
1.50: Shall scatter thousand wounds on tender hearts:
1.51: Thy shafts themselves will fly, thy neighb'ring fire
1.52: Will catch mens' breasts, and kindle warm desire.
1.53:
Thus conqu'ring Bacchus looks in
						Indian groves,
1.54: He drawn by tigers, thou by murm'ring doves.
1.55: Well then, since I too can increase thy train,
1.56: Spend not thy force on me, and rage in vain;
1.57: Look on thy kinsman Caesar's happy slaves,
1.58: The same victorious arm that conquers, saves.

2.0: Be just, dear maid, an equal passion prove,
2.1: Or show me cause why I should ever love.
2.2: I do not at your cold disdain repine,
2.3: Nor ask your love, do you but suffer mine.
2.4: I dare not aim at more exalted bliss,
2.5: And Venus will bestow her vot'ry this.
2.6: Take hin, who will for endless ages serve:
2.7: Take him whose faithful flame will never swerve
2.8: Though no illustrious names my race adorn;
2.9: Who am but of equestrian order born;
2.10: Though a few ploughs serve my paternal fields,
2.11: Nor my small table many dishes yields;
2.12: Yet Bacchus, Phoebus, and the tuneful nine,
2.13: Are all my friends, and to my side incline,
2.14: And love's great god, at last, will make me thine.
2.15: Heav'n knows, dear maid, I love no other fair;
2.16: In thee lives all my love, my heav'n lies there.
2.17: Oh! may I by indulgent Fate's decree,
2.18: With thee lead all my life, and die with thee.
2.19: Thy beauties yield me my transporting theme;
2.20: And while I celebrate thy charming name,
2.21: My verse shall be as sacred as my flame.
2.22: Jove's sev'ral rapes, his injur'd Io's wrongs,
2.23: Are made immortal in his poet's songs.
2.24: Verse still reveals where Leda's flames began,
2.25: Rais'd by the secret godhead in the swan,
2.26: The story of the rape Europa bore,
2.27: Shall last while winds shall rage, or waters roar.
2.28: Your name shall live like theirs, while verse endures,
2.29: And mine be ever writ, and read with yours.

3.0: Your husband will be with us at the treat,
3.1: May that be the last supper he shall eat.
3.2: And am poor I, a guest invited there,
3.3: Only to see, while he may touch the fair?
3.4: To see you kiss, and hug your nauseous lord,
3.5: While his lewd hand descends below the board?
3.7: At such a sight, the Centaurs urg'd to arms:
3.8: That in a rage, they threw their cups aside,
3.9: Assail'd the bridegroom, and would force the bride.
3.10: I am not half a horse, (I would I were :)
3.11: Yet hardly can from you my hands forbear.
3.12: Take, then, my counsel; which observ'd, may be,
3.13: Of some importance both to you and me.
3.14: Be sure to come before your man be there,
3.15: There's nothing can be done, but come howe'er.
3.16: Sit next him, (that belongs to decency;)
3.17: But tread upon my foot in passing by.
3.18: Read in my looks what silently they speak,
3.19: And slily, with your eyes, your answer make.
3.20: My lifted eye-brow shall declare my pain,
3.21: My right hand to his fellow shall complain;
3.22: And on the back a letter shall design,
3.23: Beside a note that shall be writ in wine.
3.24: Whene'er you think upon our last embrace,
3.25: With your fore-finger gently touch your face.
3.26: If any word of mine offend my dear,
3.27: Pull with your hand the velvet of your ear;
3.28: If you are pleas'd with what I do or say,
3.29: Handle your rings, or vith your fingers play.
3.30: As suppliants use at altars, hold the board,
3.31: Whene'er you wish the devil may take your lord.
3.32: When he fills for you, never touch the cup,
3.33: But bid th' officious cuckold drink it up:
3.34: The waiter on those services employ;
3.35: Drink you, and I will snatch it from the boy,
3.36: Watching the part where your sweet mouth hath been,
3.37: And thence, with eager lips, will suck it in.
3.38: If he, with clownish manners, thinks it fit
3.39: To taste, and offer you the nasty bit,
3.40: Reject his greasy kindness, and restore
3.41: Th' unsav'ry morsel he had chew'd before.
3.42: Nor let his arms embrace your neck, nor rest
3.43: Your tender cheek upon his hairy breast;
3.44: Let not his hand within your bosom stray,
3.45: And rudely with your pretty bubbies play.
3.46: But, above all, let him no kiss receive,
3.47: That's an offence I never can forgive;
3.48: Do not, oh! do not that sweet mouth resign,
3.49: Lest I rise up in arms, and cry 'tis mine.
3.50: I shall thrust in betwixt, and void of fear
3.52: These things are plain to sight, but more I doubt
3.53: What you conceal beneath your petticoat;
3.54: Take not his leg between your tender thighs,
3.55: Nor with your hand provoke my foe to rise.
3.56: How many love inventions I deplore,
3.57: Which I myself have practis'd all before !
3.58: How oft have I been forc'd the robe to lift
3.59: In company; to make a homely shift
3.60: For a bare bout, ill huddled o'er in haste,
3.61: While o'er my side the fair her mantle cast!
3.62: You to your husband shall not be so kind,
3.63: But lest you should, your mantle leave behind.
3.64: Encourage him to tope, but kiss him not,
3.65: Nor mix one drop of water in his pot.
3.66: If he be fuddled well, and snores apace,
3.67: Then we may take advice from time and place.
3.68: When all depart, while compliments are loud,
3.69: Be sure to mix among the thickest crowd;
3.70: There I will be, and there we cannot miss,
3.71: Perhaps to grubble, or at least to kiss.
3.72: Alas, what length of labor I employ,
3.73: Just to secure a short and transient joy!
3.74: For night must part us, and when night is come
3.75: Tuck'd underneath his arm, he leads you home.
3.76: He locks you in, I follow to the door,
3.77: His fortune envy, and my own deplore;
3.78: He kisses you, he more than kisses too,
3.79: Th' outrageous cuckold thinks it all his due.
3.80: But add not to his joy by your consent,
3.81: And let it not be given, but only lent;
3.82: Return no kiss, nor move in any sort,
3.83: Make it a dull and a malignant sport.
3.84: Had I my wish he should no pleasure take,
3.85: But slubber o'er your bus'ness for my sake;
3.86: And whate'er fortune shall this night befall,
3.87: Coax me to morrow by forswearing all.

4.0: 'Twas noon when I, scorch'd with the double fire
4.1: Of the hot sun and my more hot desire,
4.2: Stretch'd on my downy couch at ease was laid,
4.3: Big with expectance of the lovely maid.
4.4: The curtains but half drawn, a light let in
4.5: Such as in shades of thickest groves is seen,
4.6: Such as remains when the sun flies away,
4.7: Or when night's gone, and yet it is not day.
4.8: This light to modest maids must be allow'd,
4.9: Where shame may hope its guilty head to shroud.
4.10:
And now my love Corinna did
						appear,
4.11: Loose on her neck fell her divided hair;
4.12: Loose as her flowing gown, that wanton'd in the air.
4.13: In such a garb, with such a grace and mien,
4.14: To her rich bed came the Assyrian queen;
4.15: So Lais looked when all the youth of Greece
4.16: With adoration did her charms confess.
4.17: Her envious gown to pull away I tried,
4.18: But she resisted still, and still denied;
4.19: But so resisted that she seem'd to be
4.21: So I at last an easy conquest had,
4.22: Whilst my fair combatant herself betray'd.
4.23: But when she naked stood before my eyes,
4.24: Gods, with what charms did she my soul surprise!
4.25: What snowy arms did I both see and feel!
4.26: With what rich globes did her soft bosom swell!
4.27: Plump as ripe clusters rose each glowing breast,
4.28: Courting the hand, and suing to be press'd!
4.29: What a smooth plain was on her belly spread,
4.30: Where thousand little loves and graces play'd!
4.31: What thighs! what legs ! but why strive I in vain,
4.32: Each limb, each grace, each feature to explain
4.33: One beauty did through her whole body shine;
4.34: I saw, admir'd, and press'd it close to mine
4.35: The rest who knows not? Thus entranc'd we lay,
4.36: Till in each other's arms we died away;
4.37: 0 give me such a noon, ye gods, to ev'ry day!

5.0: Slave, if thou worthy of thy chains wouldst be,
5.1: A grateful office do to love and me.
5.2: Unbar the wicket, and a friend admit;
5.3: The trouble is not much, nor favour great.
5.4: I ask thee not to spread the foldings wide;
5.5: Keep it at jar,-I'll softly by thee slide.
5.6: I to love's labours have so long been us'd,
5.7: My shapes are to a lath's lank size reduc'd.
5.8: The smallest crevice will my bus'ness do,
5.9: It cannot be so straight but I'll slip through.
5.10: Love guides me when by night I walk the street,
5.11: And when I grope my way directs my feet.
5.12: By night I was a youth afraid to walk,
5.13: Frighted by children and old nurses' talk;
5.14: I wonder'd men could wander in the gloom,
5.15: And kept, for fear of spirits, close at home.
5.16: Love and his mother, when they knew my care,
5.17: Cried, "Fool, thou shalt not long these phantoms fear."
5.18: Nor fear'd I long, for love my heart possess'd;
5.19: Those visions vanish'd, and my terrors ceas'd:
5.20: Nor ghosts nor scourers did I dread, but stroll'd
5.21: The streets a-nights, and grew in peril bold.
5.22: Thee only do I fear, and trembling stand
5.23: To wait the motions of thy tardy hand:
5.24: With soft request thy succour I implore,
5.25: Nor sue to Jove nor dread the Thund'rer more.
5.26: See how the gate is moistened with my tears!
5.27: What marks of my impatient love it bears!
5.28: Remember, when thou for the lash wert stripp'd
5.29: Who sav'd thee, at whose suit thou wert not whipp'd.
5.30: Did not I sooth thy angry lady's mind,
5.31: And make thy peace? Be thou to me as kind.
5.32: Think what soft things to move her soul I said,
5.33: And let them in a lover's favour plead.
5.34: But ah! the tender things that made her kind,
5.35: Work no such wonders on thy cruel mind.
5.36: Wouldst thou my friendly offices repay,
5.37: Fate throws a fair occasion in thy way;
5.38: Unlock the gate, the morning will not stay.
5.39: Unlock the gate; and as thou'rt kind to me,
5.40: So may thy gentle lady prove to thee;
5.41: May she to loose thy hateful chains incline,
5.42: And stead of water, be thy portion wine.
5.43: But what avail my soothing words? Thy ear
5.44: Is deaf, inhuman! to my moving pray'r.
5.45: Your gates with posts of pond'rous oak are barr'd,
5.46: As if your house was for a siege prepar'd;
5.47: Why all this fence? what foe have you to fear?
5.48: And why in peace do you provide for war?
5.49: Thus rudely if your lady's friends you treat,
5.50: What usage must her foes expect to meet?
5.51: Unlock the gate,-the morning will not stay;
5.52: Unlock the gate, and give my love its way.
5.53: Or is it sloth or is it sleep that brings,
5.54: This let to love, and pinions down his wings!
5.55: Why else do I in vain repeat my prayer,
5.56: Is it, thou dost not, or thou wilt not hear?
5.57: When first I waited at thy gate, and thought
5.58: To 'scape thy care, I was at midnight caught.
5.59: With over-dilligence thou then look'st out,
5.60: To spy what lover was upon the scout.
5.61: These are wild guesses, thou'rt perhaps employ'd
5.62: More sweetly, and enjoy'st what I enjoy'd.
5.63: And while I'm waiting with impatience here,
5.64: Thy envied fortune's with the faithless fair.
5.65: Oh, for thy pleasure, give me all thy pains,
5.66: Let us change chances, and be mine thy chains.
5.67: Unlock the gate, the morning will not stay,
5.68: Unlock the gate, and kindness past repay.
5.69: Hark: or I dream, or on the hinge I hear
5.70: The wicket turn, or bolts unloosen'd jar.
5.71: I dream, indeed, the bolts as they were laid,
5.72: Stand fix'd: the noise was by my fancy made.
5.73: But all, alas! is hush'd, I hear no sound,
5.74: All in the silence of the night is drown'd.
5.75: Here, hopeless of admittance, I attend,
5.76: While on my head the pearly dews descend.
5.78: Unlock the gate, I will no longer pray,
5.79: But force by sword and fire my readier way.
5.80: What need of fire or sword? myself alone,
5.81: More pow'rful, than or sword or fire am grown.
5.82: Around your heads shall flaming torches fly,
5.83: And Jove the house shall burn, as well as I.
5.84: Night, love, and wine encourage and inflame:
5.85: These triumph over fear, and that o'er shame.
5.86: All ways I've tried, but all successless prove,
5.87: Nor threats can fright thee, nor entreaties move;
5.88: Deaf to my pray'rs as to my tears thou'rt blind,
5.89: Thy gate is less obdurate than thy mind.
5.90: But see, the ruddy morn begins to rise,
5.91: And paints with rosy streaks the eastern skies,
5.92: While crowing cocks the lab'rer's sloth revile,
5.93: And summon wretches to their daily toil.
5.94: Throw then, fond man, thy fragrant chaplet by,
5.95: And let it at thy lady's threshold lie.
5.96: When in the morn thy faded flow'rs she spies,
5.97: Kind thoughts of me may in her bosom rise,
5.98: Perhaps she may resent her porter's crime,
5.99: And grieve that here so ill I spent my time.
5.100: Against me though thou shut'st thy lady's gate,
5.101: I cannot one, that serves my mistress, hate.
5.102: You both who did against my hopes rebel,
5.103: Ah, porter; and ah, cruel gate, farewell.

6.0: Come, if ye're friends, and let these hands be bound,
6.1: Which could with impious rage a mistress wound:
6.2: What more did Ajax in his fury do,
6.3: When all the sacred grazing herd he slew?
6.4:
Or he who spared
						not her who gave him breath?
6.5: So ill the son reveng'd his father's death!
6.6: Then I had broke the most religious ties,
6.7: Both to my parents and the deities:
6.8: I tore (0 heav'ns!) her finely braided hair,
6.9: How charming then look'd the disorder'd fair.
6.10: So Atalanta in her chaise is drawn,
6.11:
Where the Arcadian beasts her empire
						own:
6.12: So Ariadne, left upon the shore,
6.13: Does all alone her lost estate deplore.
6.14: Who would not then have rail'd and talk'd aloud
6.15: (Which to the helpless sex might be allowed.)
6.16: She only did upbraid me with her eye,
6.17: Whose speaking tears did want of words supply.
6.19: Had struck me lame before that fatal hour,
6.20: And not have suffer'd me to pierce my heart
6.21: So deeply, in the best and tend'rest part;
6.22: To make a lady that subjection own,
6.23: Which is not to the meanest Roman known.
6.24: 'Twas Diomede, who first a goddess struck,
6.25: I from his hand that curs'd example took;
6.26: But he was far less criminal than I,
6.27: I was a lover, he an enemy.
6.28: March like a conqueror in triumph now,
6.29: With laurel wreaths encompassing your brow,
6.30: And render to the mighty gods your vow:
6.31: So, as you pass, th' attending gazing crowd,
6.32: By their applause shall speak your courage loud:
6.33: Let your sad captive in the front appear,
6.34: With streaming cheeks, and with dishevell'd hair.
6.35: Such lips were form'd for kinder words than these,
6.36: Wounds made by lovers' furious ecstasies.
6.37: Though like a torrent I was hurried on,
6.38: A slave to passion which I could not shun,
6.39: I might have only pierc'd her tender ear
6.40: With threatening language, such as virgins fear.
6.41: Fear having chill'd the current of her blood,
6.42: She pale as Parian marble statue stood;
6.43: Tears, which suspense did for a while restrain,
6.44: Gush'd forth, and down her cheeks the deluge ran.
6.45: As when the sun does by a powerful beam
6.46: Dissolve the frost, it runs into a stream.
6.47: The lamentable objects struck me dead,
6.48: And tears of blood to quench those tears I shed;
6.49: Thrice at her feet the prostrate suppliant fell,
6.50: And thrice did she repulse the criminal.
6.51: What would I not your anger to abate,
6.52: Redeem your favour, or remove your hate?
6.53: To your revenge no means or method spare;
6.54: Revenge, alas! is easy to the fair.

7.0:
There is a bawd renown'd in Venus '
						wars,
7.1: Aud dreadful still with honorable scars;
7.2: Her youth and beauty, craft and guile supply,
7.3: Sworn foe to all degrees of chastity.
7.4: Dypsas, who first taught love-sick maids the way
7.5: To cheat the bridegroom on the wedding-day,
7.6: And then a hundred subtle tricks devis'd,
7.7: Wherewith the am'rous theft might be disguis'd;
7.8: Of herbs and spells she tries the guilty force,
7.9: The poison of a mare that goes to horse.
7.10: Cleaving the midnight air upon a switch,
7.11: Some for a bawd, most take her for a witch.
7.12: Each morning sees her reeling to her bed,
7.13: Her native blue o'ercome with drunken red:
7.14: Her ready tongue ne'er wants a useful lie,
7.15: Soft moving words, nor charming flattery.
7.16:
Thus I o'erheard her to my Lucia 
						speak:
7.17:
"Young Damon 's heart wilt thou for
						ever break
7.18: He long has lov'd thee, and by me he sends
7.19: To learn thy motions, which he still attends;
7.20: If to the park thou go'st, the plays are ill;
7.21: If to the plays, he thinks the air would kill.
7.22: The other day he gaz'd upon thy face,
7.23: As he would grow a statue in the place;
7.24: And who indeed does not? like a new star,
7.25: Beauty like thine strikes wonder from afar.
7.26: Alas! methinks thou art ill-dress'd to-night;
7.27: This point's too poor; thy necklace is not right;
7.28: This gown was by some botching tailor made,
7.29: It spoils thy shape; this fucus is ill laid.
7.30: Hear me, and be as happy as thou'rt fair:
7.31: Damon is rich, and what thou wanst, can spare.
7.32: Like thine his face, like thine his eyes are thought.
7.33: Would he not buy, he might himself be bought."
7.34:
Fair Lucia blush'd. "It is a sign of
						grace,
7.35: (Dypsas replied,) that red becomes thy face.
7.36: All lovers now by what they give are weighed,
7.37: And she is best belov'd that best is paid;
7.38: The sun-burnt Latins, in old Tatius' reign,
7.39: Did to one man perhaps their love restrain:
7.40: Venus in her Aeneas' city rules,
7.41: And all adore her deity but fools.
7.42: Go on, ye fair, chaste only let such live
7.43: As none will ask, and know not how to give.
7.44: Life steals away, and our best hours are gone
7.45: Ere the true use or worth of them be known.
7.46: Things long neglected, of themselves decay;
7.47: What we forbear, time rudely makes his prey.
7.48: Beauty is best preserv'd by exercise,
7.49: Nor for that task can one or few suffice.
7.50: Wouldst thou grow rich, thou must from many take:
7.51: From one 'twere hard continually to rake.
7.52: Without new gowns and coaches, who can live ?
7.53: What does thy poet but new verses give?
7.54: A poet, the last thing that earth does breed,
7.55: Whose wit, for sixpence, any one may read.
7.56: Hang the poor lover, and his pedigree;
7.57: The thriving merchant, or fat judge, give me.
7.58: Love truly none, but seem in love with all,
7.59: And at old friends to thy new lovers rail.
7.61: The sharp-set hawks will stoop to any lure.
7.62: Then grant again, lest he a habit get
7.63: Of living from thee; but be sure thou let
7.64: No empty lover in; murmur sometimes,
7.65: And at first hurt, reproach him with thy crimes.
7.66: Seem jealous, when thou'st been thyself to blame;
7.67: 'Twill stop his mouth, if thou the first complain.
7.68: All thou hast done be ready to forswear:
7.69:
For lovers' oaths fair Venus has no
						ear.
7.70: Whilst lie is with thee, let some woman bring
7.71: Some Indian stuff or foreign precious thing;
7.72: Which thou must say thou want'st, and he must buy,
7.73: Though for it six months hence in gaol he lie.
7.74: Thy mother, sister, brother, and thy nurse,
7.75: Must have a pull each at thy lover's purse.
7.76: Let him from rivals never be secure,
7.77: That hope once gone, love will not long endure;
7.78: Show him the presents by those rivals sent,
7.79: So shall his bounty thy request prevent.
7.80: When he will give no more, ask him to lend:
7.81: If he wants money, find a trusting friend.
7.83: Or any thing for which his word will pass.
7.84: Practise these rules, thou'lt find the benefit!
7.85: I lost my beauty ere I got this wit."
7.86: I at that word step'd from behind the door,
7.87: And scarce my nails from her thin cheeks forbore.
7.88: Her few gray hairs in rage I vow'd to pull,
7.89: And thrust her drunken eyes into her skull.
7.90: "Poor in a dungeon's bottom may'st thou rot,
7.91: Die with a blow with thy beloved pot;
7.92: No brandy, and eternal thirst, thy lot."

8.0: Trust me, my Atticus, in love are wars;
8.1: And Cupid has his camp, as well as Mars :
8.2: The age that's fit for war best suits with love,
8.3: The old in both unserviceable prove,
8.4: Infirm in war, and impotent in love.
8.5: The soldiers which a general does require,
8.6: Are such as ladies would in bed desire:
8.7: Who but a soldier, and a lover, can
8.8: Bear the night's cold, in show'rs of hail and rain?
8.9: One in continual watch his station keeps,
8.10: Or on the earth in broken slumbers sleeps;
8.11: The other takes his still repeated round
8.12: By mistress' house — then lodges on the ground.
8.13: Soldiers, and lovers, with a careful eye,
8.14: Observe the motions of the enemy:
8.15: One to the walls makes his approach in form,
8.16: Pushes the siege, and takes the town by storm:
8.17: The other lays his close to Celia's fort,
8.18: Presses his point, and gains the wish'd-for port.
8.19: As soldiers, when the foe securely lies
8.20: In sleep, and wine dissolv'd, the camp surprise;
8.21: So when the jealous to their rest remove,
8.22: And all is hush'd, — the other steals to love.
8.23: You then, who think that love's an idle fit,
8.24: Know, that it is the exercise of wit.
8.25: In flames of love the fierce Achilles burns,
8.26: And, quitting arms, absent Briseis mourns:
8.28: Went Hector arm'd for war, and victory.
8.30: With hair dishevell'd, and disorder'd dress,
8.31: H' admir'd the beauties of the prophetess:
8.32: The god of war was caught in th' act of love;
8.33: A story know to all the court above.
8.34: Once did I pass my hours in sloth and ease,
8.35: Cool shades and beds of down could only please;
8.36: When a commanding beauty rais'd my mind,
8.37: I left all little trifling thoughts behind,
8.38: And to her service all my heart resign'd:
8.39: Since, like an active soldier, have I spent
8.40: My time in toils of war, in beauty's tent:
8.41: And for so sweet a pay all dangers underwent.
8.42: You see, my Atticus, by what I prove,
8.43: Who would not live in idleness-must love.

9.0: Nape, who know'st so well to set the hair,
9.1: And all the fashions of the modish fair,
9.2: Like thee no lady's woman in the town
9.3: Can forward an intrigue, or pin a gown;
9.4: No maid than thee can boast a quicker eye,
9.5: Nor sooner the sour husband's coming spy.
9.6: Here, Nape, take this billet-doux, and bear
9.7: My soul's soft wishes to the absent fair.
9.8: If I can guess, thy heart is not of flint,
9.9: Nor is there the least vein of iron in't;
9.10: I something in thy looks and manners see
9.11: Above the rudeness of thy low degree;
9.12: A softer turn, to pity more inclined,
9.13: Than vulgar souls, a more complacent mind;
9.14: Thou feel'st, if I can guess, an equal flame,
9.15: And thine and my distemper is the same.
9.16: If how I do, she asks, do thou reply,
9.17: For the dear night, and night's dear joys, I die.
9.18: Tell her the letter will the rest explain,
9.19: And does my soul, and all its hopes contain.
9.20: But time, while I am speaking, flies: be sure
9.21: To give the billet in a leisure hour:
9.22: Don't be content with her imperfect view,
9.23: But make her, when she has it, read it through.
9.24: I charge thee, as she reads, observe her eyes,
9.25: Catch, if thou canst, her gentle looks and sighs;
9.26: As these are sure presages of my joy,
9.27: So frowns and low'rs my flattering hopes destroy.
9.28: Pray her, when she has read it, to indite
9.29: An answer, and a long epistle write.
9.30: I hate a billet, where at once I view
9.31: A page all empty, but a line or two.
9.32: Let her without a margin fill it up,
9.33: And crowd it from the bottom to the top.
9.34: But why should I her pretty fingers tire?
9.35: A word's enough, and all that I desire.
9.36: Ah, Nape, let her only bid me come;
9.37: The page is large, which for that word has room.
9.38: Her letter, like a conqu'ror's, shall be bound
9.39: With bays, for it with conquests shall be crown'd.

10.0: Ah, pity me, my friends! the cruel fair
10.1: Will neither read my just complaint, nor hear.
10.2: The billet-doux I sent her she return'd,
10.3: And e'en to ope the tender letter scorn'd
10.4: Ill was the omen, for the slave I sent
10.5: Trip'd at the sill as out of doors he went.
10.6: If e'er you on an errand go for me,
10.7: More careful, sirrah! how you stumble, be;
10.9: The end's ne'er right if the beginning's wrong.
10.10: Sinee thus in vain her pity I implore,
10.11: I'll ne'er to tablets trust my passion more;
10.12: Nor with my wax for death my warrant seal;
10.13: Worse than her scorn, what torture can I feel?
10.14: From combs of Cosica the wax was ta'en,
10.15: The latent poison was the lover's bane.
10.16: Bees there from venom'd flow'rs their honey suck,
10.17: And surely to my wax that venom stuck.
10.18: Chance on the seal did my misfortune paint,
10.19: And show'd my doom by the vermilion teint.
10.20: Curse on the instruments of my disgrace !
10.21: May you lie rotting in some filthy place;
10.22: By carts run o'er may you to bits be torn,
10.23:
And your mishap revenge Corinna 's
						scorn !
10.24: The man that first to smooth your surface toil'd,
10.25: The wooden work with hands impure defil'd;
10.26: Gibbets and racks should of the wood be made,
10.27: And the rough tools of all the murd'ring trade.
10.28: Bats roosted in its branches as it grew,
10.29: And birds of prey for shelter thither flew:
10.30: The vulture, and all kind of rav'nous fowl,
10.31: There hatch their young, and there the om'nous owl.
10.32: How mad to use such tablets must I be?
10.33: Curst and ill fated, as their parent tree!
10.34: Were these fit things soft sentiments to bear,
10.35: And to a lady tell a lover's care?
10.36: Lawyers, on you, might horrid jargon write,
10.37: With sound the ear, with sense the soul to flight.
10.38: Well might your plain the wicked writings bear
10.39: Where the rich miser robs the ruin'd heir.
10.40: When I first purchas'd you, I feared no less,
10.41: Your numbers even made me doubt success:
10.42: May you by worms be in old age devour'd,
10.43: And by all mortals as by me abhor'd.

11.0: Aurora, rising from old Tithon's bed,
11.1: Does o'er the eastern skies her roses spread:
11.2: Stay, beauteous morn, awhile thy chariot stay,
11.3: Awhile with lagging wheels retard the day.
11.4: So may young birds, as often as the spring
11.5: Renews the year, o'er Memnon's ashes sing.
11.6:
Now I lie folded in Corinna 's
						arms,
11.7: And all her soul is mine, and all her charms;
11.8: I now am to her panting bosom press'd,
11.9: And now, if ever lover was, am bless'd.
11.10: As yet sweet sleep sits heavy on our eyes,
11.11: And warbling birds forbid, as yet to rise.
11.12: Stay, beauteous morning, for to love-sick maids
11.13: And youths, how grateful are these dusky shades!
11.14: All stay, and do not, from the blushing east,
11.15: With dawning glories break our balmy rest.
11.16: When night's black mantle does those glories hide,
11.17: The pilot by the stars his ship can guide,
11.18: And in mid-sea a certain course pursue,
11.19: As safe as when he has the sun in view.
11.20: What pleasure in thy light should mortals take?
11.21: Thou dost the weary traveller awake;
11.22: Though to the down his heavy head reclines,
11.23: Up he must lift it for the morning shines.
11.24: The soldier braces on his brazen shield,
11.25: Quits his warm tent, and fits him for the field:
11.26: The lab'ring hind his harrow takes, and now
11.27: The peasant yokes his oxen to the plough:
11.28: The boy half wak'd, and rubbing still his eyes,
11.29: Is loth alike to go to school, or rise;
11.30: While o'er his task he does imperfect nod,
11.31: He fears the ferula, he dreads the rod.
11.32: The bridegroom, starting from his bride's embrace,
11.33: Runs to his lawyer to consult his case;
11.34: A word is wanting in the dower deed,
11.35: And what to save the portion must he plead?
11.36: Now hungry serjeants quit their tempting ease,
11.37: To haunt the crowded courts and pick up fees.
11.38: Thy rise brings labour to the female band,
11.39: And puts the spindle in the spinster's hand:
11.40: Light are these toils, and little is the pain
11.41: To rise to work, and rest at night again;
11.42: But who that e'er knew love's transporting joys,
11.43: Could from the arms of youth and beauty rise?
11.44: Oft have I wish'd that night would keep her ground,
11.45: And all her stars be at thy rising found;
11.46: Oft have I wish'd the winds would stop thy way,
11.47: Repel thy car, or clouds involve the day.
11.48: Dost thou in envy lash each lazy steed,
11.49: And whirl thy chariot with unwonted speed?
11.50: Black was thy son, and in his hue's express'd
11.51: The gloomy passions of his parent's breats;
11.52: He, born of Cephalus, his ravish'd sire,
11.53: Is a known proof of thy adult'rous fire.
11.54: Thou, by his colour, wouldst thy crime conceal;
11.55: Ah, that to Tithon I the tale could tell!
11.56: Search all the records of Heaven's lechers round,
11.57: A fouler story cannot there be found.
11.58: In Cephalus' embraces when you lay,
11.59: And oft by theft renew'd your wanton play;
11.60: When Tithon's impotence you made your sport,
11.61: Did you not think the joyous moments short?
11.62: Lock'd in his arms did you in transports lie,
11.63: Ah! would you not, like me, to Phoebus cry,
11.64: "Stop, stop thy rapid course? Am I to blame
11.65: That Tithon's old, and cannot feel thy flame?
11.66: See how the moon does her Endymion keep
11.67: In night conceal'd, and drown'd in dewy sleep.
11.68: As lovely is the moon, as fair as thou,
11.69: Who freely, where she loves, her favours does bestow.
11.70: Jove, when he rob'd Amphitryon of his joy,
11.71: Did two whole nights in am'rous thefts employ;
11.72: Unknown when in Alcmena's arms he lay,
11.73: The night he doubles and suspends the day."
11.74: The morning heard my railing, and for shame
11.75: Blush'd that by force she must disturb my flame;
11.76: Bright Phoebus rushing forth, the glorious day
11.77: Drove the dear shades, that hid our joys, away.

12.0: I us'd to warn you, not with so much care,
12.1: And waste of ointment, to adorn your hair:
12.2: That warning now is useless, you have none,
12.3: And with your hair that trouble too is gone.
12.4: Where are the silken tresses, which adown
12.5: Your shoulders hung? A web was never spun
12.6: So fine, but, ah! those flowing curls are gone.
12.7: Ah fatal art! ah fatal care, and pains!
12.8: That robb'd me of the dearest of my chains.
12.9: Nor of a black, nor of a golden hue
12.10: They were, but of a dye between the two.
12.11: How could you hurt, or poison with perfume,
12.12: Those curls that were so easy to the comb?
12.13: That to no pains expos'd you, when you set
12.14: Their shining tresses for young hearts a net?
12.15: That ne'er provok'd you with your maids to war,
12.16: For hurting you with your entangled hair?
12.17: You ne'er were urg'd to some indecent fray,
12.18: Nor in a fury snatch'd the comb away.
12.19: The teeth ne'er touch'd you, and her constant care,
12.20: Without ill arts, would have preserv'd your hair.
12.21: Behind your chair I oft have seen her stand,
12.22: And comb and curl it with a gentle hand:
12.23: Oft have I seen it on your shoulders play
12.24: Uncomb'd, as on your purple bed you lay.
12.25: Your artless tresses with more charms appear,
12.26: Than when adorn'd with all your cost and care.
12.27: When on the grass the Thracian nymphs recline,
12.28:
Of Bacchus full, and weary of their
						wine,
12.29: Less lovely are their locks, than yours, less fair
12.30: The ringlets of their soft dishevell'd hair:
12.31: Softer was thine, like fleecy down it felt,
12.32: And to the finger did as freely yield,
12.33: How didst thou torture it, the curls to turn,
12.34: Now with hot irons at thy toilet burn?
12.35: This rack, with what obedience did it bear?
12.36: "Ah spare," I cried, "thy patient tresses spare!
12.37: To hurt them is a sin: this needless toil
12.38: Forbear, and do not, what adorns thee, spoil.
12.39: 'Tis now too late to give your labour o'er,
12.40: Those tortur'd ringlets are, alas ! no more.
12.41: Ah, cease the cruel thought, and cease to pass
12.42: Such irksome minutes at your faithful glass !
12.43: In vain thou seek'st thy silken locks to find;
12.44: Banish the dear remembrance from thy mind.
12.45: No weeds destroy'd them with their pois'nous juice,
12.46: Nor canst thou witches' magic charms accuse,
12.47: Nor rival's rage, nor dire enchantment blame,
12.48: Nor envy's blasting tongue, nor fever's flame.
12.49: The mischief by thy own fair hands was wrought;
12.50: Nor dost thou suffer for another's fault.
12.51: How oft I bade thee, but in vain, beware
12.52: The venom'd essence, that destroy'd thy hair?
12.53: Now with new arts thou shalt thy pride amuse,
12.54: And curls, of German captives borrow'd, use.
12.55:
Drusus to Rome their vanquish'd
						nation sends
12.56: And the fair slave to thee her tresses lends.
12.57: With alien locks thou wilt thy head adorn,
12.58: And conquests gain'd by foreign beauties scorn.
12.59: How wilt thou blush, with other charms to please,
12.60: And cry, "How fairer were my locks than these !"
12.61: By heav'ns, to heart she takes her head's disgrace,
12.62: She weeps, and covers with her hands her face.
12.63: She weeps, as in her lap her locks she views;
12.64: What woman would not weep, such locks to lose!
12.65: Ah, that they still did on her shoulders flow,
12.66: Ah, that they now, where once they grew, did grow!
12.67:
Take courage, fair Corinna , never
						fear,
12.68: Thou shalt not long these borrow'd tresses wear:
12.69: Time for your beauty shall this loss repair
12.70: And you again shall charm with native hair.

0.0: How hard's my hap, to have my fair consign'd
0.1: To one, who is imperfect in his kind;
0.2: To one, who ne'er can have the pow'r to prove
0.3: As woman, or as man, the mutual joys of love!
0.4: Who practis'd first on boys the cutting steel,
0.5: Deserv'd himself the fatal wound to feel.
0.6: Couldst thou be capable of Cupid's fires,
0.7: Or the least sensible of love's desires,
0.8: Some pity thou wouldst have on me, and grant
0.9: Thy aid, for what thou canst not know I want.
0.10: Ill suits thee now, the warrior's lance to wield,
0.11: To mount the manag'd horse, or lift the brazen shield:
0.12: Arms are for men, and not for such as thee,
0.13: Who shouldst from ev'ry manly thought be free.
0.14: No banner shouldst thou, but thy lady's bear,
0.15: And have no other leader but the fair.
0.16: Much it behoves thee then to strive to gain
0.17: Her favour, and thou need'st not strive in vain.
0.18: Consult her pleasure, and her will obey,
0.19: To favour that's the sure, the ready way:
0.20: Without it, how unhappy wilt thou be!
0.21: Life is without it of no use to thee.
0.22: Thou'rt beautiful, and mayst thy prime enjoy,
0.23: And well thy beauty and thy youth employ.
0.24: Study to serve thy gentle mistress well,
0.25: And merit her good graces by thy zeal;
0.26: Watch as thou wilt, the trouble thou mayst spare,
0.27: She'll easily deceive thy utmost care.
0.28: When two fond lovers are agreed to meet,
0.29: Canst thou their well-concerted plot defeat?
0.30: The ways of kindness thou shouldst rather use;
0.31: By being civil thou wilt nothing lose;
0.32: And when an opportunity is fail,
0.33: For thy own sake be friendly to our pray'r.
0.34: A friend be to thy lady, not a guard,
0.35: And we, with bounteous hand, thy friendship will reward.

1.0: Vice by my verse I never will defend,
1.1: Nor by false arms to fence my own pretend.
1.2: Frankly my failings I with shame confess;
1.3: To hide my errors would not make them less.
1.4: My faults, whate'er I suffer by't, I own,
1.5: That others, if they please, those faults may shun
1.6: I hate myself, my follies, and would fain
1.7: Be, were it in my pow'r, another man.
1.8: How difficult it is, ye righteous Gods,
1.9: Against our wills to bear such heavy loads.
1.10: I have not strength to guard myself from ill,
1.11: And, as I wish, to rule my wicked will.
1.12: I'm hurry'd on, as by the boistrous sea
1.13: The driving bark is swiftly borne away.
1.14: No certain form inflames my am'rous breast,
1.15: All beauty is alike to me the best;
1.16: A hundred causes kindle my desires,
1.17: And love ne'er wants a torch to light my fires.
1.18: When on the earth the modest virgin looks,
1.19: That very modesty of hers provokes;
1.20: And if I chance to meet a forward fair,
1.21: I'm taken with her frank and easy air:
1.22: I figure to myself a thousand charms,
1.23: A thousand raptures in her wanton arms.
1.24:
If, like the damsels of the Sabine 
						race,
1.25: She's rude, I look upon it as grimace;
1.26: That sullen as she seems at first, 'tis art,
1.27: That I the more may prize the conquest or her heart.
1.28: New joys, if she's a wit, I hope to find;
1.29: And with her body, to possess her mind:
1.30: If foolish, I in that can see no harm,
1.31: And in her very folly find a charm.
1.32: I know a maid so very fond, and dull,
1.33: To me she thinks Callimachus a fool.
1.34: I soon am pleas'd with one that's pleas'd with me,
1.35: Alike we in our taste and wish agree:
1.36: But if the fair my verses don't approve,
1.37: I bragging tell her, she will like my love;
1.38: If with her tongue, or with her heel she's brisk,
1.39: Her prattle pleases, and her gamesome frisk;
1.40: But if she's heavy, I suppose at night
1.41: She'll change, and prove, as I would have her, light,
1.42: The fair that sings, enchants me with her voice;
1.43: Oh, what a gust it gives a lover's joys!
1.44: When her shrill shakes afresh his bosom wound,
1.45: And from her lips he kisses off the sound;
1.46: When her soft fingers touch the silver strings,
1.47: And sweetly to the sounding lute she sings;
1.48: Who can resist such strong redoubled charms?
1.49: Her music melts me, as her beauty warms
1.50: If in the dance the nimble nymph I find,
1.51: And view how she her pliant limbs does wind,
1.52: How artfully she to the music moves,
1.53: I cry, "How happy is the man she loves!"
1.54: My humour, in a word, is plainly this,
1.55: All objects please, and nothing comes amiss.
1.56: To love, and be belov'd my sole employ:
1.57: Dispos'd to be enjoy'd, and to enjoy.
1.58: This lady for her length I like, her spread
1.59: Will swell my arms, and fill the joyous bed;
1.60: She's like the lusty heroines of old,
1.61: And with a strong embrace her lover will enfold.
1.62: This lass, because she's little, I approve;
1.63: The least are lightest in the sports of love.
1.64: With every size my passion does agree,
1.65: And tall and short are both alike to me.
1.66: I fancy, when undress'd I find the fair,
1.67: 'Tis less her want of charms, than want of care.
1.68: If with her dishabille, I cry, " I'm pleas'd,"
1.69: How beauteous would she be if she were dress'd
1.70: And when she does her best apparel wear,
1.71: I think her riches in her pride appear.
1.72: The fair, the olive, are to me the same,
1.73: Alike the swarthy, and the sandy dame.
1.74: When her black curls adown her shoulders flow,
1.75: Such Leda's were, her skin as white as snow;
1.76: And when her golden locks her head adorn,
1.77: I straight compare her to the saffron morn.
1.78: My love with no complexion disagrees,
1.79: But all alike my ready passion please.
1.80: The younger by their bloom my heart secure,
1.81: The elder win it as they're more mature;
1.82: And though the younger may excel in charms,
1.83: The elder clasp you with experienc'd arms
1.84: What all the city like, is liked by me,
1.85: And I with them and all my loves agree.
1.86: I'm proud to be the rival of the town,
1.87: And to their taste will still conform my own.

2.0: Cupid, be gone! I can for beauty sigh,
2.1: But not be forc'd to wish each hour to die;
2.2: For so I wish whene'er my restless thoughts
2.3: Dwell on her falsehoods and repeated faults.
2.4: All other plagues know sometimes to be civil,
2.5: But woman is a sure, perpetual evil.
2.6: No pimp I bribe to prove thy perjur'd vows,
2.8: 0, cou dst thou but my arguments disprove!
2.9: A cause so good is here unwish'd in love.
2.10: Happy, who dares t' avow his censur'd flame,
2.11: And vindicate the secret tripping dame.
2.12: Blushless, tho' guilty, with uplifted eyes,
2.13: "'Tis false, my life, by yon bright Heaven," she cries.
2.14: Himself he fools, and madly feeds his grief,
2.15: Who from conviction seeks the sad relief.
2.16: Wretched I saw thy wantonness unsought,
2.17: By thee in sleep secure and eyeless thought;
2.18: With glances on each other how you hung!
2.19: How ev'ry nod had more than half a tongue!
2.20: How roll'd thy glowing eyes! how lewd they spoke!
2.21: E'en from thy artful fingers language broke;
2.22: While writing on the board with pens they vied,
2.23: And the spilt wine the want of ink supplied.
2.24: The silent speech too well I understood,
2.25: For to deceive a lover yet who could?
2.26: Tho' thou didst write in a laconic hand,
2.27: And words for sentences were taught to stand.
2.28: Now ended was the treat, and ev'ry guest
2.29: Indulg'd his ease, and lay compos'd to rest:
2.30: Your close, lascivious kisses then I spied,
2.31: And something more than lips to lips applied;
2.32: Such from a sister brothers ne'er receive,
2.33: But yielding fair ones to warm lovers give.
2.34:
Not so Diana would to Phoebus
						press,
2.35:
But Cytherea so her Mars would
						bless.
2.36: Too far provok'd, at last I cried aloud,
2.37: "On whom are pleasures, due to me, bestow'd?
2.38: I must not, will not, cannot bear this sight;
2.39: 'Tis lawful, sure, to seize upon my right.
2.40: These raptures to us both in common are,
2.41: But whence, ye furies, claims a third his share?"
2.42: Enrag'd I spoke, and o'er her cheeks were spread
2.43: Swift newborn glories in a sudden red;
2.44: Such blushes on the bridal night adorn
2.45: The trembling virgin; such the rising morn.
2.46:
So sweet a hue the lab'ring Cynthia 
						shows,
2.47: Or the fair lily damask'd by the rose;
2.48: Or iv'ry, which time's yellow taint defies,
2.49: When twice enrich'd with proud Assyrian dies:
2.50: Such were her looks, and a diviner grace
2.51: Had never brighten'd that enchanting face.
2.52: She cast her eyes down on the humble ground;
2.53: Her eyes, so cast, an unknown sweetness found.
2.54: Mournful her looks; her mournful looks became
2.55: Shining thro' grief, and beautiful in shame.
2.56: I rush'd, resolv'd her golden locks to tear,
2.57: And with mad violence disrobe the fair;
2.58: But as I viewed her face, th' extended hand
2.59: Shrunk back, nor hearken'd to the harsh command.
2.60: Others protection seek by dint of arms,
2.61: Her only safeguard was -- her wondrous charms.
2.62: I, who but late look'd insolently brave,
2.63: Fell from my height, and couch'd a suppliant slave:
2.64: I rav'd no longer at another's bliss,
2.65: But begg'd the transport of as sweet a kiss.
2.66: Smiling she said, " How grateful thy request!
2.67: If e'er my kisses please thee, take the best."
2.68: Oh, with what gust as from her soul they came!
2.69: Such might melt Jove, and stop the vengeful flame;
2.70: I fear'd my rival too enjoy'd the same.
2.71: These, better than from me she learn'd I thought,
2.72: Something taught new, alas! I wish'd untaught;
2.73: What most gave pleasure, that now stings the most;
2.74: Why were our darting tongues entirely lost?
2.75: Nor fret I thou in kissing shouldst excel,
2.76: And yet 'tis strange to know to kiss so well;
2.77: But ah! such lectures only could be read
2.78: By youthful tutors, and imbib'd abed.
2.79: That sage who'er these large improvements made,
2.80: Was by his pupil preciously repay'd.

3.0: Alas! poor Poll, my Indian talker, dies!
3.1: Go, birds, and celebrate his obsequies;
3.2: Go, birds, and beat your breasts, your faces tear,
3.3: And pluck your gaudy plumes instead of hair;
3.4: Let doleful tunes the frighted forest wound,
3.5: And your sad notes supply the trumpet's sound.
3.6: Why, Philomel, dost mourn the Thracian rage?
3.7: It is enough, thy grief at last assuage;
3.8: His crimson faults are now grown white with age.
3.9: Now mourn this bird; the cause of all thy woe
3.10: Was great, 'tis true, but it was long ago.
3.11: Mourn, all ye wing'd inhabitants of air,
3.12: But you, my turtle, take the greatest share;
3.13: You too liv'd constant friends and free from strife
3.14: Your kindness was entire, and long as life:
3.15: What Pylades to his Orestes vow'd.
3.16: To thee, poor Poll, thy friendly turtle show'd,
3.17: And kept his love as long as fate allow'd.
3.18: But, ah! what did thy faith, thy plumes, and tail,
3.19: And what thy pretty speaking art, avail?
3.20: And what that thou wert giv'n, and pleas'd my miss,
3.21: Since now the bird's unhappy glory dies ?
3.22: A lovely verdant green grac'd ev'ry quill,
3.23: The deepest vivid red did paint thy bill;
3.24: In speaking thou didst ev'ry bird excel,
3.25: None prattled, and none lisp'd the words so well.
3.26: 'Twas envy only sent this fierce disease;
3.27: Thou wert averse to war, and liv'dst in peace,
3.28: A talking harmless thing, and lov'dst thine ease.
3.29: The fighting quails still live 'midst all their strife,
3.30: And even that, perhaps, prolongs their life.
3.31: Thy meat was little, and thy prattling tongue
3.32: Would ne'er permit to make thy dinner long:
3.33: Plain fountain water all thy drink allow'd,
3.34: And nut and poppy-seed were all thy food.
3.35: The preying vultures and the kites remain,
3.36: And the unlucky crow still caws for rain;
3.37: The chough still lives 'midst fierce Minerva 's hate,
3.38: And scarce nine hundred years conclude her fate;
3.39: But my poor Poll now hangs his sickly head,
3.40: My Poll, my present from the east, is dead.
3.41: Best things are sooner snatch'd by cov'tous fate,
3.42: To worse she freely gives a longer date;
3.44:
And Hector fell, whilst all his
						brothers liv'd.
3.45:
Why should I tell what vows Corinna 
						made?
3.46: How oft she begg'd thy life, how oft she pray'd ?
3.47: The seventh day came, and now the Fates begin
3.48: To end the thread, they had no more to spin;
3.49: Yet still he talk'd, and when death nearer drew,
3.50:
His last breath said, " Corinna , now
						adieu!"
3.51: There is a shady cypress grove below,
3.52: And thither (if such doubtful things we know)
3.53: The ghosts of pious birds departed go;
3.54: 'Tis water'd well, and verdant all the year,
3.55: And birds obscene do never enter there;
3.56: There harmless swans securely take their rest,
3.57: And there the single Phoenix builds her nest;
3.58: Proud peacocks there display their gaudy train,
3.59: And billing turtles coo o'er all the plain:
3.60: To these dark shades my parrot's soul shall go,
3.61: And with his talk divert the birds below;
3.62: Whilst here his bones enjoy a noble grave,
3.63: A little marble, and an epitaph:-
3.64: "In talking I did ev'ry bird excel,
3.65: And my tomb proves my mistress lov'd me well."

4.0: And must I still be guilty, still untrue,
4.1: And when old crimes are purg'd, still charg'd with new?
4.2: What tho' at last my cause I clearly gain?
4.3: Yet I'm asham'd so oft to strive in vain,
4.4: And when the prize will scarce reward the pain.
4.5: If at the play I in fop-corner sit,
4.6: And with a squinting eye gloat o'er the pit,
4.7: Or view the boxes, you begin to fear,
4.8: And fancy straight some rival beauty there.
4.9: If any looks on me, you think you spy
4.10: A private assignation in her eye;
4.11: A silent soft discourse in ev'ry grace,
4.12: And tongues in all the features of her face.
4.13: If I praise any one, you tear your hair,
4.14: Show frantic tricks, and rage with wild despair;
4.16: I strive to cloak my passion by the cheat.
4.17: If I look well, I then neglect your charms,
4.18: Lie dull and lazy in your active arms;
4.19: If weak my voice, if pale my looks appear,
4.20: 0 then I languish for another fair.
4.21: Would I did sin, and you with cause complain,
4.22: For when we strive to shun, yet strive in vain,
4.23: 'Tis comfort sure to have deserv'd the pain.
4.24: But sure fond fancies now such heats engage,
4.25: Your cred'lous peevish humour spoils your rage.
4.26: In frequent chidings I no force can see,
4.27: You frown too often to prevail with me;
4.28: The ass grows dull by stripes; the constant blow
4.29: Beats off his briskness, and he moves but slow.
4.30: But now I'm lavish of my kind embrace,
4.31: And Moll, forsooth, supplies her lady's place!
4.32: Kind love, forbid that I should stoop so low;
4.33: What! unto mean, ignoble beauties bow ?
4.34: A chambermaid ! no faith, my love flies high;
4.35: My quarry is a miss of quality.
4.36: Fye, who would clasp a slave ? who joy to feel
4.37: Her hands of iron and her sides of steel ?
4.38: 'Twill damp an eager thought, 'twill check my mind,
4.39: To feel those knobs the lash hath left behind.
4.40: Besides, she dresses well, with lovely grace
4.41: She sets thy tow'r, and does adorn thy face;
4.42: Thy nat'ral beauty all her hearts improve,
4.43: And make me more enamour'd of my love.
4.44: Then why should I tempt her, and why betray
4.45: Thy useful slave, and have her turn'd away?
4.46:
I swear by Venus , by love's darts
						and bow,
4.47: (A desp'rate oath, you must believe me now,)
4.48: I am not guilty, I've not broke my vow!

5.0:
Dear, skilful Betty , who dost far
						excel
5.1: My lady's other maids in dressing well;
5.2: Dear Betty, fit to be preferred above
5.3:
To Juno 's chamber, or the queen of
						love;
5.5: Not easy to deny desired joy;
5.6: Thro' whose soft eyes still secret wishes shine,
5.7: Fit for thy mistress' use, but more for mine;
5.8:
Who, Betty , did the fatal secret
						see?
5.9:
Who told Corinna you were kind to
						me!
5.10: Yet when she chid me for my kind embrace,
5.11: Did any guilty blush spread o'er my face!
5.12: Did I betray thee, maid, or could she spy
5.13: The least confession in my conscious eye !
5.14: Not that I think it a disgrace to prove
5.15: Stol'n sweets, or make a chambermaid my love;
5.17:
Atrides bow'd to fair Cassandra 's
						charms:
5.18: Sure I am less than these,-then what can bring
5.19: Disgrace to me, that so became a king !
5.20: But when she look'd on you, poor harmless maid,
5.21: You blush'd, and all the kind intrigue betray'd;
5.22: Yet still I vow'd, I made a stout defence,
5.23: I swore, and look'd as bold as innocence;
5.24: "Damme, -- egad!" all that, and -- "let me die!"'
5.25:
Kind Venus , do not hear my
						perjury;
5.26:
Kind Venus , stop thy ears when
						lovers lie.
5.27:
Now, Betty , how will you my oaths
						requite?
5.28: Come, pr'ythee let's compound for more delight;
5.29: Faith, I am easy, and but ask a night.
5.30: What! start at the proposal? how! deny
5.31: Pretend fond fears of a discovery ?
5.32: Refuse, lest some sad chance the thing betray ?
5.33: Is this your kind, your damn'd obliging way ?
5.34: Well, deny on; I'll lie, I'll swear no more;
5.35:
Corinna now shall know thou art a
						whore.
5.36: I'll tell, since you my fair address forbid,
5.37: How often, when, and where, and what we did!

6.0: O Love! how cold and slow to take my part,
6.1: Thou idle wanderer about my heart!
6.2: Why thy old faithful soldier wilt thou see
6.3: Oppress'd in thy own tents? they murder me;
6.4: Thy flames consume, thy arrows pierce thy friends;
6.5: Rather on foes pursue more noble ends.
6.7: A cure as certain as it gave the blow.
6.8: Hunters, who follow flying game, give o'er
6.9: When the prey's caught, hope still leads on before;
6.10: We, thine own slaves, feel thy tyrannic blows.
6.11: While thy tame hand's unmov'd against thy foes.
6.12: On men disarm'd, how can you gallant prove ?
6.13: And I was long ago disarm'd by love.
6.14: Millions of dull men live, and scornful maids;
6.15: We'll own love valiant when he these invades.
6.16:
Rome from each corner of the wide
						world snatch'd
6.17: A laurel, or't had been to this day thatch'd;
6.18: But the old soldier has his resting-place,
6.19: And the good batter'd horse is turn'd to grass:
6.20: The harass'd whore, who liv'd a wretch to please,
6.21: Has leave to be a bawd, and take her ease.
6.22: For me then, who have truly spent my blood,
6.23: Love, in thy service, and so boldly stood
6.24:
In Celia 's trenches, were't not
						wisely done,
6.25: E'en to retire, and live at peace at home ?
6.26: No-might I gain a godhead to disclaim
6.27: My glorious title to my endless flame,
6.28: Divinity with scorn I would forswear,
6.29: Such sweet, dear, tempting devils women are.
6.30: Whene'er those flames grow faint, I quickly find
6.31: A fierce black storm pour down upon my mind;
6.32: Headlong I'm hurl'd like horsemen who in vain
6.34: As ships, just when the harbour they attain,
6.35: Are snatch'd by sudden blasts to sea again,
6.36: So Love's fantastic storms reduce my heart,
6.37: Half rescu'd, and the god resumes his dart.
6.38: Strike here, this undefended bosom wound,
6.39: And for so brave a conquest be renown'd.
6.40: Shafts fly so fast to me from ev'ry part,
6.41: You'll scarce discern the quiver from my heart.
6.42: What wretch can bear a livelong night's dull rest,
6.43: Or think himself in lazy slumbers blest?
6.44: Fool-is not sleep the image of pale death?
6.45: There's time for rest when fate has stopp'd your breath.
6.46: Me may my soft deluding dear deceive,
6.47: I'm happy in my hopes, while I believe:
6.48: Now let her flatter, then as fondly chide,
6.49: Often may I enjoy, oft be denied.
6.50: With doubtful steps the god of war does move,
6.51: By thy example, in ambiguous love.
6.52: Blown to and fro, like down from thy own wing,
6.53: Who knows when joy or anguish thou wilt bring?
6.54: Yet at thy mother's and thy slave's request,
6.55: Fix an eternal empire in my breast;
6.56: And let th' inconstant charming sex,
6.57: Whose wilful scorn does lovers vex,
6.58: Submit their hearts before thy throne;
6.59: The vassal world is then thy own.

7.0: What you affirm'd, my friend, is prov'd untrue,
7.1: That none at once could madly dote on two.
7.2: Deceiv'd, unarm'd, we Cupid soon o'ercame,
7.3: And I glow shameless with a double flame.
7.4: They both are fair, both dress'd so nicely well,
7.5: That the pre-eminence is hard to tell.
7.6: Sometimes for this, sometimes for that I burn,
7.7: And each more beauteous sparkles in her turn.
7.8: Each claims my passion, and my heart divides
7.9: As to and fro the doubtful galliot rides.
7.10: Here driven by winds, and there redriven by tides.
7.11: Why doubly chain'd ? was not a single fair
7.12: Enough to load me with perpetual care?
7.13: Why are more leaves brought to the shady wood,
7.14: Stars to the sky, or waters to the flood ?
7.15: Yet better so than not to love at all;
7.16: Still on my foes may such dull blessings fall.
7.17: May they, insipidly supine, be spread
7.18: Along the middle of a widowed bed;
7.19: While I with sprightliness love's vigil's keep,
7.20: Stretch'd out for something far more sweet than sleep.
7.21: Others from ruin fly, to mine I run,
7.22: To be by women pleasingly undone,
7.23: Longing for two, since undestroy'd by one.
7.24: Still let my slender limbs for love suffice;
7.25: I want no nerves, but want the bulky size.
7.26: My limbs, tho' lean are not in vain display'd;
7.27: From me no female ever rose a maid.
7.28: Oft have I, when a luscious night was spent,
7.29: Saluted morn, nor cloy'd nor impotent.
7.30: Happy, who gasps in love his latest breath;
7.31: Give me, ye gods, so softly sweet a death !
7.32: Let the rough warriors grapple on the plain,
7.33: And with their blood immortal honour gain;
7.34: Let the vile miser plough for wealth the deep,
7.35: And, shipwrek'd in the unfatbom'd waters, sleep
7.36:
May Venus grant me but my last
						desire,
7.37: In the full height of rapture to expire.
7.38: Perhaps some friend, with kindly dew supplied,
7.39: Weeping will say, "As Ovid liv'd, he died."

8.0: Io Triumphe! I have won the prize,
8.1:
For in my arms the fair Corinna 
						lies.
8.2: Nor jealous husband, nor a guardian's care,
8.3: Nor door defended with a double bar,
8.4: Could fence against a lover's artifice,
8.6: With reason of my victory I boast,
8.7: The conquest gain'd, and yet no blood is lost;
8.8: I scal'd no walls, I pass'd no ditch profound,
8.9: Safe were my wars, and all without a wound.
8.10: My only work a charming girl to gain;
8.11: The pleasure well rewards the little pain.
8.12: Ten years the Greeks did in one siege employ,
8.13: But levell'd were, at length, the walls of Troy ;
8.14: What glory was there by th' Atrides won,
8.15: So many chiefs before a single town!
8.16: Not thus did I my pleasant toils pursue,
8.17: And the whole glory to myself is due;
8.18: Myself was horse and foot, myself alone
8.19: The captain and the soldier was in one,
8.20: And fought beneath no banner but my own.
8.21: Whether by strength I combated, or wile,
8.22: Fortune did ever on my actions smile;
8.23: I only owe my triumph to my care,
8.24: And by my patience only won the fair.
8.25: Nor was my cause of quarrel new; the same
8.26: Set Europe and proud Asia in a flame.
8.27: For Helen, ravish'd by the Dardan boy,
8.28: Was the war wag'd that sunk the pride of Troy ;
8.29: The Centaurs double form'd, half man, half beast,
8.30: Defil'd with horrid war the nuptial feast;
8.31: Inflam'd by wine and woman's magic charms,
8.32: They turn'd the jolly face of joy to arms.
8.33: 'Twas woman urg'd the strife; a second fair
8.34: Involv'd the Trojans in a second war.
8.35: What wreck, what ruin, did a Woman bring
8.36:
On peaceful Latium , and its pious
						king!
8.37:
When Rome was young and in her
						infant state
8.38: What woes did woman to our sires create!
8.39: Into what peril was that city brought,
8.40:
When Sabine fathers for their
						daughters fought !
8.41: Two lusty bulls I in the meads have view'd
8.42: In combat join'd, and by their side there stood
8.43: A milk-white heifer, who provok'd the fight,
8.44: By each contended, but the conqueror's right;
8.45: She gives them courage, her they both regard,
8.46: As one that caus'd the war, and must reward.
8.47: Compell'd by Cupid in his host to list
8.48: (And who that has a heart can love resist ?)
8.49: His soldier I have been, without the guilt
8.50: Of blood, in any of our battles spilt;
8.51: For him I've fought, as many more have done,
8.52: And many rivals met, but murder'd none.

9.0:
With cruel art Corinna would
						destroy
9.1: The ripening fruit of our repeated joy.
9.2: While on herself she practises her skill,
9.3: She's like the mother, not the child, to kill.
9.4: Me she would not acquaint with what she did,
9.5: From me a thing, which I abhorr'd, she hid;
9.6: Well might I now be angry, but I fear,
9.7: Ill as she is, I might endanger her.
9.8: By me, I must confess, she did conceive,
9.9: The fact is so, or else I so believe;
9.10: We've cause to think, what may so likely be,
9.11: So is, and then the babe belongs to me
9.12: Oh Isis, who delight'st to haunt the fields,
9.13:
Where fruitful Nile his golden
						harvest yields,
9.14: Where with seven mouths into the sea it falls,
9.15: And hast thy walks around Canope's walls,
9.16:
Who Memphis visit'st, and the
						Pharian tower,
9.17:
Assist Corinna with thy friendly
						powers.
9.18: Thee by thy silver Sistra I conjure,
9.19: A life so precious by thy aid secure;
9.20:
So mayst thou with Osiris still find
						grace:
9.22: I pray thee, so may still thy rights divine
9.23: Flourish, and serpents round thy offerings twine
9.24: May Apis with his horns the pomp attend,
9.25: And be to thee, as thou'rt to her, a friend.
9.26: Look down, oh Isis! on the teeming fair,
9.27: And make at once her life and mine thy care:
9.28: Have pity on her pains; the help you give
9.29: To her, her lover saves, in her I live.
9.30: From thee this favour she deserves; she pays
9.31: Her vows to thee on all thy solemn days;
9.32: And when the Galli at thy altars wait,
9.33: She's present at the feast they celebrate.
9.34: And thou, Lucina, who the labouring womb
9.35: Dost with compassion view, to her assistance come:
9.36: Nor dost thou, when to thee thy votaries pray
9.37: For speedy help, thy wanted help delay.
9.39: Thy votary she, and worthy of thy care.
9.40: I'll with my off'rings to thy altar come,
9.41: With votive myrrh thy sacred fane perfume;
9.42: The vows I make that thou my fair mayst bless,
9.43: In words inscrib'd, I'll on thy shrine express:-
9.44: " Ovid , the servant of Corinna , pray'd
9.45: The goddess here, the teeming dame to aid."
9.46: Ah, goddess! of my humble suit allow;
9.47: Give place to my inscription and my vow.
9.48: If frighted as I am, I may presume
9.49: Your conduct to direct in time to come,
9.50:
Corinna , since you've suffer'd thus
						before,
9.51: Ah, try the bold experiment no more!

10.0: What boots it that the fair are free from war,
10.1: And what that they're forbid the shield to bear,
10.2: Against themselves if they knew arms employ
10.3: And madly with new wounds their lives destroy?
10.4: The cruel mother who did first contrive
10.5: Her babe to butcher ere 'twas scarce alive,
10.6: Who thus from nature's tender dictates swerv'd,
10.7: To perish by her proper hands deserv'd.
10.8: Why do the sex forget their softness? why
10.9: Such projects for a foolish fancy try?
10.10: The belly must be smooth, no wrinkle there
10.11: To shock the lover's wanton glance appear;
10.12: His touch as well as sight they fain would please,
10.13: And the womb early of its burden ease.
10.14: Had woman sooner known this wicked trade,
10.15: Among the race of men what havock had they made.
10.16: Mankind had been extinct, and lost the seed,
10.17: Without a wonder to restore the breed,
10.18: As when Deucalion and his Purrha hurl'd
10.19: The stones that sow'd with men the delug'd world,
10.20: Had Thetis, goddess of the sea, refus'd
10.21: To bear the burden, and her fruit abus'd,
10.22: Who would have Priam's royal seat destroy'd?
10.23:
Or had the vestal whom fierce Mars 
						enjoy'd,
10.24: Stifled the twins within her pergnant womb,
10.25: What founder would have then been born to Rome ?
10.26:
Had Venus , when she with Aeneas
						teem'd,
10.27: To death, ere born, Anchises' son condemn'd,
10.28: The world had of the Caesars been depriv'd;
10.29: Augustus ne'er had reign'd, nor Julius liv'd.
10.30: And thou, whose beauty is the boast of fame,
10.31: Hadst perish'd, had thy mother done the same;
10.32: Nor had I liv'd love's faithful slave to be,
10.33: Had my own mother dealt as ill by me.
10.34: Ah, vile invention, ah, accurs'd design,
10.35: To rob of rip'ning fruit the loaded vine
10.36: Ah, let it grow for nature's use mature,
10.37: Ah, let it its full length of time endure;
10.38: 'Twill of itself, alas! too soon decay,
10.39: And quickly fall, like autumn leaves, away
10.40: Why barb'rously dost thou thy bowels tear
10.41: To kill the human load that quickens there?
10.42: On venom'd drugs why venture, to destroy
10.43: The pledge of pleasure past, the promis'd boy?
10.44: Medea, guilty of her childrens' blood,
10.45: The mark of ev'ry age's curse has stood;
10.46: And Atys, murder'd by his mothers rage,
10.47: Been pitied since by each succeeding age;
10.48: Thy cruel parents by false lords abus'd,
10.49: Had yet some plea, tho' none their crime excus'd.
10.50: What, Jason, did your dire revenge provoke?
10.51: What, Tereus, urge you to the fatal stroke?
10.52: What rage your reason led so far away,
10.53: As furious hands upon yourself to lay?
10.54: The tigresses that haunt th' Armenian wood,
10.55: Will spare their proper young, though pinch'd for food;
10.56: Nor will the Libyan lionesses slay
10.57: Their whelps, -- but woman are more fierce than they;
10.58: More barb'rous to the tender fruit they bear,
10.59: Nor nature's call, tho' loud she cries, will hear.
10.60: But righteous vengeance oft their crimes pursues,
10.61: And they are lost themselves, who would their
10.63: The pois'nous drugs with mortal juices fill
10.64: Their veins, and, undesign'd, themselves they kill
10.65: Themselves upon the bier are breathless borne,
10.66: With hair tied up that was in ringlets worn,
10.67: Thro' weeping crowds that on their course attend;
10.68: Well may they weep for their unhappy end.
10.69: Forbid it, heaven, that what I say may prove
10.70: Presaging to the fair I blame and love;
10.71: Thus let me ne'er, ye pow'rs, her death deplore,
10.72: 'Twas her first fault, and she'll offend no more;
10.73: No pardon she'll deserve a second time,
10.74: But, without mercy, punish then her crime.

11.0: Go, happy ring, who art about to bind
11.1: The fair one's finger; may the fair be kind.
11.2: Small is the present, tho' the love be great;
11.3: May she swift slip thee on thy taper seat.
11.4: As she and I, may thou with her agree,
11.5: And not too large, nor yet too little be.
11.6: To touch her hand thou wilt the pleasure have;
11.7: I now must envy what myself I gave.
11.8: O! would a Proteus or a Circe change
11.9: Me to thy form, that I like thee might range !
11.10: Then would I wish thee with her breasts to play,
11.11: And her left hand beneath her robes to stray.
11.12: Tho' straight she thought me, I will then appear
11.13: Loose and unfix'd, and slip I know not where.
11.14: Whene'er she writes some secret lines of love,
11.15: Lest the dry gum and wax should sticking prove,
11.16: He first she moistens : then sly care I take,
11.17: And but, when lines I like, impression make.
11.18: Of in her pocket fain she would me hide,
11.19: Close will I press her finger, and not slide;
11.20: Then cry, "My life, I ne'er shall thee disgrace,
11.21: And I am light; give me my proper place.
11.22: Still let me stick when in the bath you are;
11.23: If I catch damage,'tis not worth your care.
11.24: Yea, when the ring thy naked body spies,
11.25: It will transform, and I a man arise."
11.26: Why do I rave? thou little trifle, go,
11.27: And that I die for her let the dear creature know.

12.0: I'm now at -- where my eyes can view,
12.1: Their old delights, but what I want in you:
12.2: Here purling streams cut thro' my pleasing bowr's,
12.3: Adorn my banks, and raise my drooping flow'rs;
12.4: Here trees with bending fruit in order stand,
12.5: Invite my eye, and tempt my greedy hand;
12.6: But half the pleasure of enjoyment's gone;
12.7: Since I must pluck them single and alone;
12.8: Why could not nature's kindness first contrive,
12.9: That faithful lovers should like spirits live,
12.10: Mix'd in one point and yet divided lie,
12.12: But since we must thro' distant regions go,
12.13: Why was not the same way design'd for two?
12.14: One single care determined still for both,
12.15: And the kind virgin join'd the loving youth?
12.16: Then should I think it pleasant way to go
12.17: Oe'r Alpine frost, and trace the hills of snow;
12.18: Then should I dare to view the horrid moors,
12.19: And walk the deserts of the Libyan shores;
12.20:
Hear Scylla bark, and see Charybdis 
						rave,
12.21: Suck in and vomit out the threat'ning wave;
12.22: Fearless through all I'd steer my feeble barge,
12.23: Secure, and safe with the celestial charge,
12.24: But now, though here my grateful fields afford
12.25: Choice fruits to cheer their malancholy lord;
12.26: Though here obedient streams the gard'ner leads,
12.27: In narrow channels through my flow'ry beds;
12.28: The poplars rise, and spread a shady grove,
12.29: Where I might lie, my little life improve,
12.30: And spend my minutes 'twixt a muse and love:
12.31: Yet these contributes little to my ease,
12.32: For without you they lose the power to please;
12.33: I seem to walk oe'r the fields of naked sand,
12.34: Or tread an antic maze in fairy land,
12.35: Where frightful specires, and pale shades appear,
12.36: And hollow groans invade my troubled ear;
12.37: Where ev'ry breeze that through my arbour flies,
12.38: First sadly murmurs, and then turns to sighs.
12.39: The vines love elms; what elms from vines remove?
12.40: Then why should I be parted from my love?
12.41: And yet by me you once devoutly swore,
12.42: By your own eyes, those stars that I adore,
12.43: That all my bus'ness you would make your own,
12.44: And never suffer me to be alone:
12.46: Their frequent oaths are like the falling leaves,
12.47: Which when a storm has from the branches tore
12.48: Are lost by ev'ry blast, and seen no more:
12.49: Yet if you will be true, your vows retrieve,
12.50: Be kind, and I can easily forgive ;
12.51: Prepare your coach, to me direct your course,
12.52: Drive fiercely on, and lash the lazy horse;
12.53: And while you ride I will prolong the day,
12.54: And try the power of verse to smooth your way.
12.55: Sink down ye mountains, sink ye lofty hills,
12.56: Ye vallies be obedient to her wheels,
12.57: Ye streams be dry, ye hindr'ing woods remove,
12.58: 'Tis love that drives, and all must yield to love !

13.0: If there's a wretch, who thinks it is a shame,
13.1: To serve a lovely and a loving dame:
13.2: If such a slave he loads with infamy,
13.3: I'm willing he should judge as hard of me;
13.4: I'm willing all the world should know my shame
13.5:
If Venus will abate my raging
						flame.
13.6: Let me a fair and gentle mistress have,
13.7: And then proclaim aloud that I'm her slave.
13.8: Beauty is apt to swell a maiden's mind,
13.9:
And thus Corinna is to pride
						inclin'd:
13.10: But as she is above all maiden's fair,
13.11: What's pride in them is insolence in her;
13.12: Less fair I wish she was, or knew it less;
13.13: How learnt she, she is lovely by her face!
13.14: Her mirror tells her so, she often tries
13.15: Her mirror, and believes her charming eyes.
13.16: The looks she then puts on, are still her best,
13.17: And she ne'er uses it but when she's dress'd.
13.18: Though wide the empire of your beauties spread,
13.19: Beauty to draw my am'rous glances made:
13.20: Compare your servant's merit with your eyes,
13.21: You'll find no cause his service to dispise.
13.22: Don't think I press upon your pride too hard.
13.23: For little things may be with great compar'd:
13.24: We're told Calypso, an immortal pow'r,
13.25: Detain'd a mortal in th' Ogygian pow'r,
13.26: And when her pray'r to stay he would not grant,
13.27: So strong her love, she kept him by constraint.
13.28: A Nereid took the Pythian to her arms.
13.29: And Numa knew divine Egeria 's charms.
13.30:
Vulcan though lame, and of a form
						obscene,
13.31: Was oft made happy by the Paphian queen;
13.32: She matter'd not his limping, but approv'd
13.33: His flame, and saw no faults in him she lov'd
13.34: My verses are unequal like his feet,
13.35: Yet the long kindly with the shorter meet.
13.36: As they with them, why shouldst thou not with me
13.37: Comply, my life and my divinity !
13.38: Myself, when I am in thy arms, I'll own
13.39: Thy subject, and the bed shall be thy throne;
13.40: Thou there, my lovely queen, shall give me laws,
13.41: Nor in my absence, to rejoice have cause,
13.42: Nor ever shall my services be blam'd
13.43: Nor shalt thou of thy servant be asham'd.
13.44: My poetry's my purse, my fortun's there,
13.45: I have no other way to win the fair;
13.46: Nor is that way the worst; the brightest dames
13.47: Would in my verse immortalize their names.
13.48: My muse the place of an estate supplies,
13.49: And none that know her worth, her wealth despise.
13.50:
Some tempted by Corinna 's spreading
						fame,
13.51: In envy rob her, and usurp her name;
13.52: What would they give, d'ye think, to be the same ?
13.53: But neither could Eurotas, nor the Po,
13.54: With poplar shaded, in one channel flew;
13.55: By diff'rent, and by distant banks they glide,
13.56: Are rivers both, but various in their tide.
13.57: There are more beauties, but there's none like thine,
13.58: There are more versed, but thou hast only mine;
13.59: No other charms can e'er inspire my muse,
13.60: And other themes I with disdain refuse.

14.0: While, Macer, you Achilles' choler sing,
14.1:
And Greece before the walls of
							 Ilium bring;
14.2: While feats of arms in Phrygian fields you tell,
14.3: And how old Tory by Grecion vengeance fell;
14.4: I my soft hours in softer songs employ,
14.5: And all my leisure give to love and joy.
14.6: When to high acts, my voice I strive to raise,
14.7: Love laughs at my attempt, and mocks my lays;
14.8: "Begone!" I often to my mistress cry,
14.9: But have not courage, yet, myself to fly.
14.10: Whene'er she sees me in this sullen fit,
14.11: She fondles me, and, on my knee will sit:
14.12: "Enough of this (say I), for shame give o'er,
14.13: Enough of love, we'll play the fool no more."
14.14: " Ah, is it then a shame to love?" she cries,
14.15: And chides, and melts me with her weeping eyes.
14.16: Around my neck her snowy arms she throws,
14.17: And to my lips with stifling kisses grows.
14.18: How can I all this tenderness refuse ?
14.19: At once my wisdom, and my will I lose;
14.20: I'm conquer'd, and renounce the glorious train
14.21: Of arms, and war, to sing of love again:
14.22: My themes are acts, which I myself have done,
14.23: And my muse sings no battles but my own.
14.24: Once I confess I did the drama try,
14.25: And ventur'd with success on tragedy;
14.26: My genius with a moving scene agrees,
14.27: And if I ventured further I might please:
14.28: But love my heroics makes a jest,
14.29: And laughs to see me in my buskins drest.
14.30: Asham'd, and weary of this tragic whim,
14.31: For tender thoughts I quitted the sublime.
14.32: My mind my mistress bends another way,
14.33: Her must my muse in all her songs obey;
14.34: Though oft I do not what I write approve,
14.35: Like, or not like it, I must sing of love.
14.37: To great Ulysses I a letter frame,
14.38: Or for Oenone tender things indite,
14.39: Or soft complaints for injur'd Phillis write;
14.41: I sooth, or flatter Dido's fierce despair;
14.42: Whether I fan Medea's raging fire,
14.43: Or for sweet Sappho touch the Lesbian lyre;
14.44: Whether I Phaedra's lawless love relate,
14.45: Or Theseus' flight and Ariadne's fate:
14.46: Oh, that Sabinus, my departed friend,
14.47: Could from all quarters now his answers send!
14.48: Ulysses' hand should to his queen be known,
14.49: And wretched Phaedra hear from Theseus' son;
14.53: A sad reply, and Sappho cease to mourn:
14.54: Nor him whom she can ne'er possess, desire,
14.55: But give to Phoebus fane her votive lyre.
14.56: As much as you in lofty epics deal,
14.57: You, Macer, show that you love's passion feel,
14.58: And sensible of beauty's powerful charm,
14.59: You hear their call amid the noise of arms.
14.60:
A place for Paris in your verse we
						find,
14.61: And Helen's to the young adult'rer kind;
14.62: There lovely Laodamia mourns her lord,
14.63:
The first that fell by Hector 's
						fatal sword.
14.64: If well I know you, and your mind can tell,
14.65: The theme's as grateful, and you like as well
14.66: To tune your lyre for Cupid as for Mars ,
14.67: And Thracian combats change for Paphian wars;
14.68: If well I know you, and your works design
