14.69: Your will, you often quit your camp for mine.

15.0: If for thyself thou wilt not watch thy whore,
15.1: Watch her for me that I may love her more.
15.2: What comes with ease we nauseously receive,
15.3: Who but a sot would scorn to love with leave?
15.4: With hopes and fears my flames are blown up higher;
15.5: Make me despair, and then I can desire.
15.6: Give me a jilt to tease my jealous mind;
15.7: Deceits are virtues in the female kind.
15.9: Play'd trick for trick, and kept herself still new;
15.10: She, that next night I might the sharper come,
15.11: Fell out with me, and sent me fasting home.
15.12: Or some pretence to lie alone would take ;
15.13: Whene'er she pleas'd her head and teeth would ache:
15.14: Till having won me to the highest strain,
15.15: She took occasion to be sweet again.
15.16: With what a gust, ye gods, we then embrac'd!
15.17: How ev'ry kiss was dearer than the last!
15.18: Thou whom I now adore, be edified,
15.19: Take care that I may often be denied;
15.20: Forget the promis'd hour, or feign some fright,
15.21: Make me lie rough on bulks each other night.
15.22: These are the arts that best secure thy reign,
15.23: And this the food that must my fires maintain.
15.24: Gross easy love does, like gross diet, pall;
15.25: In squeasy stomachs honey turns to gall.
15.26: Had Danae not been kept in brazen tow'rs,
15.27: Jove had not thought her worth his golden show'rs:
15.28:
When Juno to a cow turn'd Io's
						shape,
15.29: The watchman help'd her to a second leap.
15.30: Let him who loves an easy whetstone whore,
15.31: Pluck leaves from trees, and drink the common shore.
15.32: The jilting harlot strikes the surest blow,
15.33: A truth which I by sad experience know;
15.34: The kind, poor, constant creature we despise,
15.35: Man but pursues the quarry while it flies.
15.36: But thou dull husband of a wife too fair,
15.37: Stand on thy guard, and watch the precious ware;
15.38: If creaking doors, or barking dogs, thou hear,
15.39: Or windows scratch'd, suspect a rival there.
15.40: An orange wench would tempt thy wife abroad;
15.41: Kick her, for she's a letter-bearing bawd.
15.42: In short, be jealous as the devil in hell,
15.43: And set my wit on work to cheat thee well.
15.44: The sneaking city-cuckold is my foe;
15.45: I scorn to strike but when he wards the blow.
15.46: Look to thy hits and leave off thy conniving,
15.47: I'll be no drudge to any wittol living;
15.48: I have been patient, and forborne thee long,
15.49: In hope thou wouldst not pocket up thy wrong:
15.50: If no affront can rouse thee, understand
15.51: I'll take no more indulgence at thy hand.
15.52: What, ne'er to be forbid thy house and wife
15.53: Damn him who loves to lead so ill a life.
15.54: Now I can neither sigh, nor whine, nor pray;
15.55: All those occasions thou hast ta'en away.
15.56: Why art thou so incorrigibly civil ?
15.57: Do somewhat I may wish thee at the devil
15.58: For shame, be no accomplice in my treason;
15.59: A pimping husband is too much in reason.
15.60: Once more wear horns, before I quite forsake her
15.61: In hopes whereof, I rest thy cuckold-maker.

0.0: Unhurt by steel, arose an ancient wood,
0.1: A mansion fit for some retiring god;
0.2: With craggy stones a secret grot was hung,
0.3: And in the midst a sacred fountain sprung;
0.4: The courting birds repeating songs of love,
0.5: With soft complainings sweetly fill'd the grove:
0.6: Here wand'ring thoughtful, and intent to choose
0.7: Some theme unsung, to please the busy muse;
0.8: Fair elegy came on with gentle pace,
0.9: Unforc'd her air and easy was her grace.
0.10: Her flaxen hair, in curious tresses wreath'd,
0.11: Ambrosial sweets and heav'nly odours breath'd;
0.12: A simple dress the careless charmer bore,
0.13: And loving looks, and smiles unartful wore.
0.14: Next came the goddess of the tragic scene,
0.15: With stately tread, and proud majestic mien
0.16: Her front severe, with hanging curls was drown'd,
0.17: Her length of robe was full, and swept the ground:
0.18: Her hand held out, a regal sceptre grac'd,
0.19: And Lydian buskins half her legs embrac'd.
0.20: She first; "Must love for ever tune thy voice,
0.21: Fond idle bard, and trifling in thy choice
0.22: Thy wanton songs employ the drunkard's tongue,
0.23: In ev'ry street thy ribald lays are sung;
0.24: The finger marks thee in thy passing by,
0.25: 'Behold, where goes the slave of love,' they cry.
0.26: Thy lewd exploits, thou profligate, are grown
0.27: The public theme, and talk of all the town;
0.28: Whilst unconcern'd, and lost to sense of shame,
0.29: Thou still runn'st on nor mind'st thy ruin'd fame.
0.30: Enough thou'st told the plaints of fond desire,
0.31: Now let a nobler inspiration fire;
0.32: Thy matter cramps thy genius, learn to find
0.33: A manly subject, and exert thy mind.
0.34: In songs for girls, fond toys, and idle play,
0.35: Thy muse has wanton'd all her hours away.
0.36: But youth at length has fill'd its measure up;
0.37: My friend, 'tis time to taste of t'other cup.
0.38: Now in my service let thy force be shown,
0.39: Assert my honour, and retrieve thy own;
0.40: Thy sprightly fancy, and inventive wit,
0.41: The lofty style of tragic scenes will fit."
0.42: She said; and proudly rising in her gait,
0.43: Thrice shook her tresses, and display'd her state.
0.44: With open look (nor was my sight beguil'd)
0.45: And joyous eyes her rival sweetly smil'd;
0.46: Sustain'd her hand a myrtle branch upright?
0.47: Or did my fancy form the charming sight?
0.49: And canst thou ne'er forego thy sullen pride?
0.50: I not compare my lowly lays to thine;
0.51: Too weak materials for the vast design.
0.52: The style unlabour'd, negligent the dress,
0.53: My verse is humbler, and my matter less.
0.54: Gay, wanton, soft, my business is to move,
0.55: With melting strains, the playful god of love.
0.56:
Bereft of me, fair Venus wants her
						charms,
0.57: I help the goddess, and prepare her arms.
0.58: My luring art, and soothing lays prevail,
0.59: Where lofty port, and tragic buskins fail.
0.60: I more deserve, by making that my care,
0.61: Thy rigid pride allows not thee to bear:
0.62:
By me, Corinna first was taught to
						try
0.63: Tobreak from prison, and deceive the spy;
0.64: I first induc'd the fearful fair to slide
0.65: With tremb'ling caution from her husband's side;
0.66: When to thy arms, all loose, and disarray'd,
0.67: Prepar'd for pleasure, flew the melting maid.
0.68: Fix'd on her door, how oft I've hung on high,
0.69: Expos'd, and patient of each gazing eye !
0.70: How oft, in secret, while the keeper stay'd,
0.71: Within her woman's panting bosom laid !
0.72: Once sent a birthday gift, the cruel dame
0.73: In pieces tore, and gave me to the flame.
0.74: I taught thee first to cultivate thy mind;
0.75: Thy fancy brightened, and thy wit refin'd;
0.76: Thou to my care those merits must allow,
0.77: For which my rival would seduce thee now;"
0.78: They spoke. I answer'd, "Let me both conjure
0.79: To spare a mind with terrors unsecure;
0.80: Nor to my charge, when once pronounc'd, be laid
0.81: As crimes, the words my trembling tongue has said.
0.82: To gain me glory, thy decrees ordain
0.83: The regal sceptre and the tragic strain;
0.84: With painful labour need I toil for fame,
0.85: When easier tasks already raise my name?
0.86: Thou mak'st my love immortal; thee I choose:
0.87: Be thou my queen, and still command my muse.
0.88: Majestic pow'r, forgive my simple choice,
0.89: Thy gentle rival has obtain'd my voice.
0.90: Short is the time in which her palm is won;
0.91: Ere thine is gain'd, the poet's life is done."
0.92: I lowly said: she gracious gave assent,
0.93: And diff'rent ways the parting rivals went.
0.94: Ye gentle loves, complete the work assign'd,
0.95: A greater labour seems to press behind.

1.0: Not in the Circus do I sit to view
1.1: The running horses, but to gaze on you;
1.2: Near you I choose an advantageous place,
1.3: And whilst your eyes are fix'd upon the race,
1.4: Mine are on you -- Thus do we feast our sight,
1.5: Each alike pleas'd with objects of delight;
1.6: In softer whispers I my passion move,
1.7: You of the rider talk, but I of love.
1.8: When, to please you, I straight my subject quit
1.9: And change my wishes to your favourite;
1.10: Oh. might I ride, and be so much your care,
1.11: I'd start with courage from the barrier,
1.12: And with a swift short compass brush the goal --
1.13: Unless the sight of you my course restrains,
1.14: And makes my hands forego the loosen'd reins;
1.15: As Pelops gaz'd on Hippodamia's face,
1.16: Till he had almost lost th' important race;
1.17: Yet he his mistress by her favour won;
1.18: So may our prize assist us when we run.
1.19: "What mean these starts? you must not, can't remove:
1.20: This kind auspicious place was fram d for love.
1.21: I fear you're crowded,- Gentlemen, forbear,
1.22: Pray let your arms and knees the lady spare;
1.23: Madam, your gown hangs down-nay, pray let me --
1.24: Oh heav'ns ! what fine, what curious legs I see!
1.25:
Sure, who Diana in a forest
						drew,
1.26: Copied in this the graceful'st parts from you;
1.27: Such Atalant discovering as she ran,
1.29: I burn'd and rag'd before -- what then are these,
1.30: But flames on flames, and waters to the seas?
1.31: By these a thousand other charms are guess'd,
1.33: Oh for some air! this scorching heat remove,
1.34: Your fan would do't, but 'tis the heat of love."
1.35: But now the pomp appears, the sacred throng
1.36: Command applauses from the heart and tongue;
1.37: First victory with expanded wings does move,
1.38: Be near, O Goddess ! to assist my love;
1.39:
To Mars let warriors acclamations
						raise,
1.40: The merchants' tongues resound with Neptune 's praise;
1.41: Whilst I, whom neither seas nor arms invite,
1.42: In love alone, the fruit of peace, delight;
1.43: To their Apollo let the prophets pray,
1.44: And hunters to Diana homage pay.
1.45:
Let the mechanics to Minerva 
						vow,
1.46: Rustics to Ceres , and to Bacchus bow;
1.47: Whilst I devote myself to thee alone,
1.48:
Kind Venus , and the pow'rful god thy
						son;
1.50: Inform with all thy softness these fair eyes,
1.51: And to love's cause her gentle breast incline;
1.52: She grants, and has contriv'd it with a sign;
1.53: Do you assure it too, you who're to me
1.55: By all these heavenly witnesses' to you
1.56: Will I be ever faithful, ever true.
1.57: Now ib the open cirque the game's begun,
1.58: The praetor gives the signal, now they run;
1.59: I see which way your wishes are inclin'd,
1.60: To him a certain conquest is design'd;
1.61: For e'en the horses seem to know your mind.
1.62: He takes too large a compass to come in,
1.63: And lets his adversary get between;
1.64: Recall him, Romans, for a second heat,
1.66: Now see your ground you better do maintain,
1.67: This lady's favour, and your fame regain;
1.68: The prize is his.-As yours successful prove,
1.69: So let my wishes, which are all for love;
1.70: I'm yet to conquer, and your heart's the prize;
1.71: Something she promis'd with her sparkling eyes,
1.72: And smil'd ;-" Enough," did I transported cry,

2.0: Can there be gods ?-has she not falsely swore?
2.1: Yet is the beauty that she was before!
2.2: The curious tresses of her dangling hair,
2.3: As long, and graceful still as e'er they were;
2.4: That same inimitable white and red,
2.5: Which o'er her face was so distinctly spread,
2.6: The roses, and the lilies keep their place,
2.7: And ev'ry feature still as justly grace;
2.8: Her sparkling eyes their lustre still retain,
2.9: That form, that perfect shape does still remain,
2.10: As if she ne'er had sinn'd ; and heav'n, ('tis plain)
2.11: Suff'ring the fairer sex to break their vows,
2.12: To the superior pow'r of beauty bows.
2.13: T' inforce my credit to her perjuries,
2.14: Oft would she swear by those persuasive eyes;
2.15: As if that charm had been too weak to move,
2.16: Sh'as added mine;-tell me, ye pow'rs above,
2.17: Why all this pain ? why are these guiltless eyes
2.18: For her offence th' atoning sacrifice ?
2.19: Was't not enough Andromeda has died,
2.20: An expiation for her mother's pride ?
2.21: Is't not enough, that unconcern'd you see
2.22: (Vain witnesses for truth, for faith, for me,)
2.23: Such an affront put on divinity,
2.24: Yet no revenge the daring crime pursue,
2.25: But the deceiv'd must be her victim too?
2.26: Either the gods are empty notions, crept
2.27: Into the minds of sleepers as they slept,
2.28: In vain are fear'd, are but the tricks of law,
2.29: To keep the foolish cred'lous world in awe;
2.30: Or, if there be a god, he loves the fair,
2.31: And all things at their sole disposal are.
2.32: For us are all the instruments of war
2.33:
Design'd, the sword of Mars , and
							 Pallas ' spear;
2.34: 'Gainst us alone Apollo's bows are bent,
2.35: And at our hands Jove's brandish'd thunder sent.
2.36: Yet of the ladies, oh ! how fond are they !
2.37: Dare not the inj'ries they receive, repay,
2.38: But those who ought to fear them they obey.
2.39: Jove to his votaries is most severe;
2.40: Temples nor altars does his lightning spare.
2.42: But those who merit, can escape the fires.
2.43: Is this the justice of your pow'rs divine?
2.44: Who then will offer incense at a shrine ?
2.45: Why do we thus reproach the deities ?
2.46: Have they not hearts ?-and surely they have eyes,
2.47: Nay, had I been a god, I had believ'd
2.48: The lovely criminals, and been deceiv'd;
2.49: Had wav'd the judgments to their perj'ries due,
2.50: And sworn myself that all they spoke was true.
2.51: Since then the gods such ample gifts bestow,
2.52: As make you absolute o'er men below;
2.53: Pray let me find some mercy in your reign,
2.54: Or spare at least your lover's eyes from pain.

3.0: Vex not thyself and her, vain man, since all
3.1: By their own vice or virtue stand or fall.
3.2: She's truly chaste, and worthy of that name,
3.3: Who hates the ill, as well as fears the shame;
3.4: And that vile woman whom restraint keeps in,
3.5: Tho' she forbear the act, has done the sin.
3.6: Spies, locks, and bolts may keep her brutal part,
3.7: But thou'rt an odious cuckold in her heart.
3.8: They that have freedom use it least, and so
3.9: The power of ill does the design overthrow.
3.10: Provoke not vice by a too harsh restraint;
3.11: Sick men long most to drink, who know they mayn't.
3.12: The fiery courser, whom no art can stay,
3.13: Or rugged force, does oft fair means obey;
3.14: And he that did the rudest arm disdain,
3.15: Submits with quiet to the looser rein.
3.16:
A hundred eyes had Argus , yet the
						while
3.17: One silly maid did all those eyes beguile;
3.18: Danae, tho' shut within a brazen tow'r,
3.19: Felt the male virtue of the golden show'r;
3.20: But chaste Penelope, left to her own will
3.21: And free disposal, never thought of ill;
3.22: She to her absent lord preserv'd her truth,
3.23: For all th' addresses of the smoother youth,
3.24: What's rarely seen, our fancy magnifies;
3.25: Permitted pleasure who does not despise ?
3.26: Thy care provokes beyond her face, and more
3.27: Men strive to make tho cuckold than the whore.
3.28: They're wondrous charms we think, and long to know
3.29: That in a wife enchants a husband so:
3.30: Rage, swear, and curse, no matter, she alone
3.31: Pleases, who sighs, and cries, " I am undone."
3.32: But could thy spies say, " We have kept her chaste,"
3.33: Good servants then, but an ill wife thou hast;
3.34: Who fears to be a cuckold is a clown,
3.35: Not worthy to partake of this lewd town,
3.36: Where it is monstrous to be fair and chaste,
3.37: And not one inch of either sex lies waste.
3.38: Wouldst thou be happy ? with her ways comply,
3.39: And in her case lay points of honour by:
3.40: The friendship she begins, wisely improve,
3.41: And a fair wife gets one a world of love:
3.42: So shalt thou welcome be to ev'ry treat,
3.43: Live high, not pay, and never run in debt.

4.0: 'Twas in the midst and silent dead of night,
4.1: When heavy sleep oppos'd my weary sight,
4.2: This vision did my troubled mind affright:-
4.3: To Sol expos'd there stood a rising ground,
4.4: Which cast beneath a spacious shade around;
4.5: A gloomy grove of spreading oaks below,
4.6: And various birds were perch'd on ev'ry bough;
4.7: Just on the margin of a verdant mead,
4.8: Where murm'ring brooks refreshing waters spread
4.9: To shun the heat I sought this cool recess,
4.10: But in this shade I felt my heat no less;
4.11: When browzing o'er the flow'ry grass appear'd
4.12: A lovely cow, the fairest of the herd.
4.13: By spotless white distinguished from the rest,
4.14: Whiter than milk from her own udder press'd;
4.15: Whiter than falling, or the driven snow,
4.16: Before descending mists can make it flow.
4.17: She, with a lusty bull, her happy mate,
4.18: Delighted, on the tender herbage sat;
4.19: There, as he crops the flow'rs, and chews the cud,
4.20: Feasting a second time upon his food,
4.21: His limbs with sudden heaviness oppress'd,
4.22: He bends his head, and sinks to pleasing rest.
4.23: A noisy crow, cleaving the liquid air,
4.24: Thrice with lewd bill pick'd off the heifer's hair;
4.25: The glossy white imbib'd a spreading blot,
4.26: But on her breast appear'd a livid spot.
4.27: The cow rose slowly from her consort's side,
4.28: But when afar the grazing bull she spied,
4.29: Frisk'd to the herd, with an impetuous haste,
4.30: And pleas'd, in new luxuriant soil, her taste.
4.32: What may this visionary dream portend,
4.33: If dreams in any future truth can end ?
4.34: The prophet nicely weighs what I relate,
4.35: And thus denounces in the voice of fate:-
4.36: "That heat you tried to shun i' th' shady grove,
4.37: But shunn'd in vain, was the fierce heat of love.
4.38: The cow denotes the nymph, your only care,
4.39: (For white's th' expressive image of the fair,)
4.40: And you the bull, abandon'd to despair.
4.41: The picking crow some busy bawd implies,
4.42: Who with base arts will soon seduce your prim.
4.43: You saw the cow to fresher pasture range,
4.44: So will your nymph for richer lovers change;
4.45: As mixing with the herd you saw her rove,
4.46: So will the fair pursue promiscuous love;
4.47: Soon will you find a foul incestuous blot,
4.48: As on the cow you view'd the livid spot."
4.49: At this my blood retired, with dismal fright,
4.50: And left me pale as death ; my fainting sight
4.51: Was quite o'ercast in dusky shades of night.

5.0: Thy course, thy noble course a while forbear,
5.1: I am in haste now going to my dear!
5.2: Thy banks how rich, thy stream how worthy praise
5.3: Alas, my haste ! sweet river, let me pass.
5.4: No bridges here, no ferry, not an oar,
5.5: Or rope to haul me to the farther shore !
5.6: I have remember'd thee a little one,
5.7: Who now with all this flood com'st blund'ring down.
5.8: Did I refuse my sleep, my wine, my friend,
5.9: To spur along, and must I here attend ?
5.10: No art to help me to my journey's end!
5.11: Ye Lapland powers, make me so far a witch,
5.12: I may astride get over on a switch.
5.13: Or, for some griffin, or that flying horse,
5.14: Or any monster to assist my course;
5.15: I wish his art that mounted to the moon,
5.16: In shorter journey would my job be done.
5.17: Why rave I for what crack-brain'd bards devise,
5.18: Or name their lewd unconscionable lies ?
5.19: Good river, let me find thy courtesy,
5.20: Keep within bounds, and mayst thou ne'er be dry.
5.21: Thou canst not think it such a mighty boast,
5.22: A torrent has a gentle lover cross'd.
5.23: Rivers should rather take the lover's side,
5.24: Rivers themselves love's wondrous power have tried.
5.25: 'Twas on this score Inachus, pale and wan,
5.26: Sickly and green, into the ocean ran ;
5.27:
Long before Troy the ten-years siege
						did fear,
5.28:
Thou, Xanthus , thou Neaera's chains
						didst wear;
5.29: Ask Achelous who his horns did drub,
5.30:
Straight he complains of Hercules 's
						club.
5.32: Was then contested such outrageous fray!
5.33: It neither was for gold, nor yet for fee;
5.34: Dejanira, it was all for thee.
5.35: E'en Nile so rich, that rolls thro' sev'n wide doors,
5.36: And uppish over all his country scours,
5.37: For Asop's daughter did such flame contract,
5.38: As not by all that stock of water slack'd.
5.39: I might a hundred goodly rivers name,
5.40: But must not pass by thee, immortal Thame ;
5.41: Ere thou couldst Isis to thy bosom take.
5.42: How didst thou wind and wander for her sake!
5.43:
The lusty ---- with broad Humber 
						strove;
5.44: Was it for fame ? I say it was for love.
5.45:
What makes the noble Ouse up from
						the main
5.46: With hideous roar come bristling back again ?
5.47: He thinks his dearest Dervent left behind,
5.48: Or fears her false, in new embraces joined.
5.49: Thee also some small girl has warm'd, we guess,
5.50: Tho' woods and forests now hide thy soft place.
5.51: Whilst this I speak, it swells and broader grows,
5.52: And o'er the highest banks impetuous flows.
5.53: Dog-flood, what art to me ? or why dost check
5.54: Our mutual joys ? and, churl, my journey break ?
5.55: What wouldst, if thee indeed some noble race,
5.56: Or high descent, and glorious name did grace ?
5.57: When of no ancient house or certain seat,
5.58: (Nor, known before this time, untimely, great)
5.59: Rais'd by some sudden thaw thus high and proud,
5.60: No holding thee, ill-manner'd upstart flood ;
5.61: Not my love-tales can make thee stay thy course,
5.62: Thou--zounds, thou art a -- river for a horse.
5.63: Thou hadst no fountain, but from bears wert pist,
5.64: From snows, and thaws, or Scotch unsav'ry mist.
5.65: Thou crawl'st along, in winter foul and poor,
5.66: In summer puddled like a common-shore.
5.67: In all thy days when didst a courtesy ?
5.68: Dry traveller ne'er laid a lip to thee.
5.69: The bane to cattle, to the meadows worse,
5.70: For something all, I for my sufferings curse.
5.71: To such unworthy wretch, how am I sham'd,
5.72: That I the gen'rous am'rous river nam'd!
5.73:
When Nile and Achelous I
						display'd,
5.74: And Thame and Ouse , what worm was in my head
5.75: For thy reward, discourteous river, I
5.76: Wish, be the summers hot, the winters dry.

6.0: Was she not heavenly fair, and rich attir'd ?
6.1: Was she not that which all my soul desir'd ?
6.2: Yet were these arms around her idly spread,
6.3: And with an useless load I press'd the bed.
6.4: E'en to my wishes was the power denied,
6.5: When with my wishes the kind nymph complied
6.6: I lay without life's animated spring,
6.7: A dull, enervate, worthless, lumpish thing.
6.8: My neck she folded with a soft embrace,
6.9: Now kissed my eyes, now wanton'd o'er my face,
6.10: Now lov'd to dart her humid tongue to mine,
6.11: Now would her pliant limbs around me twine,
6.12: And sooth, by thousand ways, the sweet design.
6.13: The moving blandishments of sound she tried,
6.14: And, " My dear life, my soul, my all," she cried.
6.15: In vain, alas ! the nerves are slacken'd still,
6.16: And I prov'd only potent in my will;
6.17: A poor inactive sign of man I made,
6.18: And might as well for use have been a shade.
6.19: If old I live, how shall I old prevail,
6.20: When in my youth I thus inglorious fail?
6.21: The bloom of years becomes my shameful moan,
6.22: Now in full growth the ripen'd man is shown,
6.23: But not the strength of man to her was known.
6.24: Untouched by brothers, sisters thus retire,
6.25: Or vestals rise to watch th' eternal fire;
6.26: Yet many a nymph whom I forbear to name,
6.27: Rave kindly yielded, and indulg'd my flame
6.28: Nor could the vigour of their 0vid blame.
6.29: Corinna knows when numb'ring the delight,
6.30: Not less than nine full transports crown'd the night.
6.31: Is verse or herbs the source of present harms ?
6.32: Am I a captive to Thessalian charms ?
6.33: Has some enchantress this confusion brought,
6.34: And in soft wax my tortur'd image wrought
6.35: Deep in the liver is the needle fix'd ?
6.36: Plagues she by numbers, or by juices mix'd?
6.37: By numbers sudden the ripe harvest die,
6.38: And fruitful urns no more their streams supply;
6.39: Oaks shed, unshook, their acorns at the call,
6.40: And the vine wonders why her clusters fall.
6.41: Why may not magic act on me the same,
6.42: Unstring the nerves, and quite untune the frame!
6.43: Gall'd at the heart, and longing to perform,
6.44: I rais'd indeed, but rais'd an empty storm;
6.45: Most disappointed when the most propense,
6.46: And shame was second cause of impotence.
6.47: What limbs I touch'd ! and only touch'd ! oh, fie!
6.48: Where was the blissful touch ? her shift can vie
6.49: In feasts like these, and touch as well as I.
6.50: Yet to touch her e'en Nestor might grow young,
6.51: And centuries, like twenty-one, be strung.
6.52: Such was the maid; the parallel had ran
6.53: Graceful, if I could add, such was the man.
6.54: Some envious deity with vengeance glow'd,
6.55: So sweet a gift had been so ill bestow'd.
6.56: I burn to clasp her naked in my arms,
6.57: Did she not freely open all her charms ?
6.58: What boots good fortune, if we want the pow'r
6.59: To snatch the pleasures of the favour'd hour?
6.60: I, like a miser, only could behold,
6.61: And brooded o'er an useless mine of gold;
6.62: So Tantalus with fruit untouch'd is curst,
6.63: And dies amid the gliding stream of thirst;
6.64: So rises early from th' untasted fair,
6.65: The grave old prelate, and kneels down to pray'r,
6.66: Were yet her melting kisses misenploy'd?
6.67: Did she strive vainly to be well enjoy'd ?
6.68: Sure she has beauties might deaf rocks enchant,
6.69: Bend the proud oak, and soften adamant;
6.70: She would have mov'd a man tho' almost dead,
6.71: But with my manhood the whole life was fled.
6.72: If none should lend an ear, why is the song,
6.73: Or painted nymphs shown to a blinded throng !
6.74: Ye gods ! what joys did not my fancy raise !
6.75: I curl'd in folds of love a thousand ways.
6.76: Strong were my thoughts, but ah ! my body lay
6.77: Languid as roses pluck'd off yesterday.
6.78: Now all the blood the circling spirits fire,
6.79: And the lost field impertinent require;
6.80: Begone untimely nerves! I trust no more,
6.81: Such was the promise of your strength before.
6.82: Could you the fair one balk of her delight,
6.83: Disgrace your master by so base a fright,
6.84: And want the courage for so sweet a fight?
6.85: Did she not kindly too your stay demand,
6.86: And tempt it softly with a soothing hand ?
6.87: But when solicitings no life could gain,
6.88: And inspirations, tho' from her, were vain;
6.89: "Who bade thee thus thyself to me to bring !
6.90: Go for a silly unperforming thing:
6.91: Art thou a wretch by some curs'd spell destroy'd,
6.92: Or here com'st fribbling with past pleasure cloy'd?"
6.93: She spoke, and springing from the bed she flew,
6.94: And secret beauties so disclos'd to view;
6.95: Yet to conceal the joyless night's digrace,
6.96: She called for water with a smiling face,
6.97: And wash'd a nameless unpolluted place.

7.0: What coxcomb will in future times think fit
7.1: To build in love his fortune on his wit ?
7.2: Wealth now is worth, whatever 'twas of old,
7.3: And merit valu'd by its weight in gold.
7.4: With male and female, this is now the rule,
7.5: And he that's poor, of course must be a fool.
7.6: The dame to read my am'rous verse delights,
7.7: My writings likes, but scorns the man that writes;
7.8: They freely on her privacy presume,
7.9: And find admittance where I must not come;
7.10: Me when she does her haunted house exclude,
7.11: To them she's civil, as to me she's rude.
7.12: Me she exposes to a thousand harms,
7.13: To walk the streets, while they are in her arms.
7.14: For whom does she my passion disregard ?
7.15: And who has intercepted my reward ?
7.16: Why is the beau with so much joy embrac'd ?
7.17: His pockets full, it seems, his coat is lac'd:
7.18: He won her with his military air
7.19: Which cheats as often as it charms the fair.
7.20: Could she her longing eyes forbear to fix
7.21: On his fine feather, and his coach and six!
7.22: Enrich'd by plunder, he could never miss
7.23: The favour, who would buy the venal bliss.
7.24: No matter how he got his wealth, by war,
7.25: And blood: she cares not, if she has her share.
7.26: The upstart forward was, 'tis said, in fight,
7.27: And in the field of battle made a knight:
7.28: But had his honour come without his gold,
7.29: His, sure, had been like my reception, cold.
7.30: To men of merit how could she be coy,
7.31: Yet to a murd'rer prostitute the joy?
7.32: That head which lolls upon your panting breast,
7.33: Was lately cover'd with a plumy crest.
7.34: Can you the bully to your bed admit ?
7.35: Are his hard limbs for ladies' dalliance fit ?
7.36: His hands in your embrace you'll find embru'd
7.37: With clotted, and perhaps with guiltless blood;
7.38: How awkward must it be for you to feel,
7.39: Near yours, his thigh that late was cas'd with steel
7.40: That ring, the token of his pride and state,
7.41: Was with a heavy gauntlet hid of late:
7.42: Canst thou have commerce with a thing so foul!
7.43: Where's now the boasted niceness of thy soul?
7.44: What pleasure canst thou in his roughness find?
7.45: Thou that wert once the softest of thy kind!
7.46: Behold what marks of brutal rage he bears,
7.47: And how he's mangled with dishonest scars.
7.48: Yet to these scars, dishonest as they are,
7.49: His wealth he owes, his fortunes with the fair.
7.50: No doubt, he makes a merit of his guilt,
7.51: And brags what blood he has in battle spilt.
7.52: Fine courtship this, to win a gentle dame;
7.53: Thou shar'st his money, and must share his shame.
7.54: Me, not the meanest of Apollo's train,
7.55: She hates, and I repeat my verse in vain;
7.56: I sing before her gate; her gate I find
7.57: Is less obdurate than her harden'd mind.
7.58: Forbear your songs, Apollo's sons, forbear,
7.59: And bend your future thoughts to arms and war.
7.61: To murder, and to rapine use your hands,
7.62: And you with ease reduce the female bands.
7.63: Had Homer in the Grecian army serv'd,
7.64: We ne'er had heard that he had begg'd, or starv'd.
7.65: Of gold the thund'rer show'd the mighty pow'r,
7.66: Descending softly thro' the brazen tow'r,
7.67: And clasping Danae in a golden show'r.
7.68: A thousand bars the virgin fair did hold,
7.69: But what are iron bars to bribes of gold?
7.70: Against this foe her father could not guard;
7.71: Watchmen, and women kept a fruitless ward.
7.72: The damsel, who herself before was coy,
7.73: Melts at the sight, and meets the dazzling joy.
7.74: When peaceful Saturn did heav'n's sceptre sway,
7.75: Deep in earth's womb the fatal metal lay;
7.76: None then their teeming mother's bowels tore,
7.77: In quest of hidden wealth, in various ore;
7.78: Fed with the fruits which bounteous nature yields,
7.79: In painted gardens, and in golden fields,
7.80: From her rich soil are reap'd spontaneous crops,
7.81: And from the forest oak sweet honey drops.
7.82: No hinds as yet did toil their time away,
7.83: Nor with keen clusters wound the parent clay:
7.84: As yet no landmark was by lab'rers set,
7.85: And none had learned to plough the sea as yet
7.86: None as yet knew the use of sails and oars,
7.87: Nor ventur'd voyages beyond their shores.
7.88: The wit of men the race of men destroys,
7.89: And all its pow'rs against itself employs.
7.90: How subtle's human nature to contrive
7.91: Its proper ruin, and itself deceive!
7.92: Why didst thou cities with high walls surround,
7.93: Why arms invent thy jarring sons to wound ?
7.94: What quarrel hast thou with the sea, and why
7.95: Didst thou at first the pathless ocean try ?
7.96: Cannot the land content thy restless pride ?
7.97: Didst thou with Saturn's sons the whole divide,
7.98: Thou wouldst not with three worlds be satisfied.
7.99: 'Tis strange thy vast ambition did not fly
7.100: O'er earth, and sea, and air, and scale the sky;
7.101: That man did not aspire to be a god,
7.102: And tread the paths by Indian Bacchus trod,
7.103: To give his name to some distinguish'd star,
7.104: And be what Hercules and Caesar are.
7.105: Instead of yellow harvests, now we seek
7.106: For solid gold, and thro' earth's entrails break;
7.107: The wealth we thus acquire's the soldier's prey,
7.108: And dearly for the blood he spills we pay.
7.109: The courts deny admittance to the poor,
7.110: In vain the needy clients crowd the door;
7.111: The judges to the rich decree the cause,
7.112: And money only gives their force to laws.
7.113: 'Tis money makes the judge with looks severe
7.114: Insult the poor, and give the rich his ear;
7.115: 'Tis money buys the title, makes the knight,
7.116: And dignifies with quality the cit:
7.117: Let money do all this, and more; the bar
7.118: Let money govern, and direct the war.
7.119: Let peace, as money sets the terms, be made,
7.120: But let it not the rights of love invade.
7.121: Let us enjoy this privilege at least,
7.122: That if we must be poor, we may with love be bless'd:
7.123: For now-a-days there's not a dame in town
7.124: So coy, but if you've money she's your own.
7.125:
What tho' her keeper may an Argus be
						?
7.126: Blind him with money, and he'll nothing see.
7.127: What though her husband should by chance be by?
7.128: He'll leave the house, let you your money fly.
7.129: If there's a god above, to whom belongs
7.130: The cause of love, and slighted lovers wrongs,
7.131: Revenge the false one's mercenary scorn,
7.132: And let ill-gotten pelf to dirt return.

8.0: If Memnon's fate bewail'd with constant dew,
8.1: Does, with the day, his mother's grief renew,
8.2: If her son's death mov'd tender Thetis' mind
8.3: To swell with tears the waves, with sighs the wind;
8.4: Sad Cupid now despairs of conqu'ring hearts,
8.5: Throws by his empty quiver, breaks his darts:
8.6: Eases his useless bows from idle strings;
8.7: Nor flies, but humbly creeps with flagging wings.
8.8: He wants, of which he robb'd fond lovers, rest;
8.9: And wounds with furious hands his pensive breast.
8.10: Those graceful curls which wantonly did flow,
8.11: The whiter rivals of the falling snow,
8.12: Forget their beauty, and in discord lie,
8.13: Drunk with the fountain from his melting eye.
8.14: Nor Phoebus, nor the muses' queen, could give
8.15: Their son, their own prerogative, to live.
8.16: Orpheus, the heir of both his parents' skill,
8.17: Tam'd wond'ring beasts, not death's more cruel will.
8.18: Linus' sad strings on the dumb lute do lie.
8.19: In silence forc'd to let their master die.
8.20: His mother weeping does his eyelids close,
8.21: And on his urn, tears, her last gift, bestows.
8.22: His sister too, with hair dishevell'd, bears
8.23: Part of her mother's nature, and her tears.
8.24: With those, two fair, two mournful rivals come,
8.25: And add a greater triumph to his tomb:
8.26: Both hug his urn, both his lov'd ashes kiss,
8.27: And both contend which reap'd the greater bliss.
8.28:
Thus Delia spoke (when sighs no more
						could last)
8.30: "When youth with vigour did for joy combine,
8.31: I was Tibullus' life, Tibullus mine;
8.32: 1 entertained his hot, his first desire,
8.33: And kept alive, till age, his active fire."
8.34: To her then Nemesis (when groans gave leave)
8.35: "As I alone was lov'd, alone I'll grieve;
8.36: Spare your vain tears, Tibullus' heart was mine,
8.37: About my neck his dying arms did twine:
8.38: I snatch'd his soul, which true to me did prove;
8.39: Age ended yours, death only stopp'd my love."
8.40: If any poor remains survive the flames,
8.41: Except thin shadows, and more empty names;
8.42: Free in Elysium shall Tibullus rove,
8.43: Nor fear a second death should cross his love.
8.44: There shall Catullus, crown'd with bays, impart
8.45: To his far dearer friend his open heart.
8.46: There Gallus (if fame's hundred tongues all lie)
8.47: Shall, free from censure, no more rashly die.
8.48: Such shall our poet's bless'd companions be,
8.49: And in their deaths, as in their lives, agree.
8.50: But thou, rich urn, obey my strict commands,
8.51: Guard thy great charge from sacrilegious hands.
8.52: Thou, earth, Tibullus' ashes gently use,
8.53: And be as soft and easy as his muse.

9.0:
Now Ceres ' feast is come, the trees
						are blown,
9.1:
And my Corinna now must lie
						alone.
9.2:
And why, good Ceres , must thy feast
						destroy
9.3: Man's chief delight, and why disturb his joy ?
9.4: The world esteems you bountiful and good,
9.5: You led us from the field and from the wood,
9.6: And gave us fruitful corn, and wholesome food.
9.7: Till then poor wretched man on acorns fed;
9.8: Oaks gave him meat, and flow'ry fields a bed.
9.9:
First Ceres made our wheat and
						barley grow,
9.10: And taught us how to plough, and how to mow;
9.11: Who then can think that she designs to prove
9.12: Our piety, by coldness in our love ?
9.13: Or make poor lovers sigh, lament, and groan,
9.14: Or charge her votaries to lie alone ?
9.15:
For Ceres , though she loves the
						fruitful fields,
9.16: Yet sometimes feels the force of love, and yields:
9.17: This Crete can witness, ( Crete not always lies)
9.18:
Crete that nurs'd Jove, and heard
						his infant cries,
9.19: There he was suckled who now rules the skies.
9.20: That Jove his education there receiv'd,
9.21: Will raise her fame, and make her be believ'd;
9.22: Nay she herself will never strive to hide
9.23: Her love, 'tis too well known to be denied:
9.24: She saw young Jasius in the Cretan grove
9.25: Pursue the deer, she saw, and fell in love.
9.26: She then perceived when first she felt the fire,
9.27: On this side modesty, on that desire;
9.28: Desire prevail'd, and then the field grew dry,
9.29: The farmer lost his crop and knew not why;
9.30: When he had toil'd, manur'd his grounds, and plough' d,
9.31: Harrow'd his fields, and broke his clods, and sow'd,
9.32: No corn appear'd, none to reward his pain,
9.33: His labour and his wishes were in vain.
9.34:
For Ceres wand'red in the woods and
						groves,
9.35: And often heard, and often told her loves:
9.36:
Then Crete alone a fruitful summer
						knew,
9.37: Where'er the goddess came a harvest grew.
9.38: Ida was grey with corn, the furious boar
9.39: Grew fat with wheat, and wonder'd at the store:
9.40: The Cretans wish'd that such all years would prove,
9.41:
They wish'd that Ceres would be long
						in love.
9.42: Well then, since then 'twas hard for you to lie
9.43: All night alone, why at your feast must I ?
9.44: Why must I mourn, when you rejoice to know
9.45: Your daughter safe, and queen of all below?
9.46: 'Tis holy-day, and calls for wine and love;
9.47: Come, let's the height of mirth and humor prove,
9.48: These gifts will please our master pow'rs above.

10.0: So much I've suffer'd, and so long, no more
10.1: I'll bear the wrongs which I have borne before.
10.2: Begone, vile Cupid, I'll no more endure
10.3: Thy slavish labors, and fatigues impure;
10.4: From hence, I'll put an end to all the pains
10.5: Thou'st cost me, and from hence shake off thy chains.
10.6: I hate the liv'ry I with pleasure wore,
10.7: And blush at bonds, which once with pride I bore:
10.8: But this, methinks, should have been done before.
10.9: To leave my wicked courses I begin,
10.10: As years deprive me of the gust of sin.
10.11: On Cupid's neck I should have trod when young,
10.12: And vanquish'd him when my desires were strong.
10.13: In that there had been virtue; now there's none,
10.14: The world will say so; let the world say on.
10.15: Much opposition I shall meet; perhaps,
10.16: The lewd will laugh, and threaten a relapse.
10.17: To bear reproaches I must be prepar'd,
10.18: Easy's the end, when the beginning's hard;
10.19: Content let me the present pain endure,
10.20: For the sharp medicine is the patient's cure.
10.21: How oft you have expos'd me to the cold,
10.22: While in your arms you did my rival hold!
10.23: How like a slave have I been forc'd to wait
10.24: All weathers, and how oft have watched the gate!
10.25: As if your house was trusted to my care
10.26: And I, your sentinel, did duty there.
10.27: Oft have I seen your sated lover come
10.28: With looks, as if he long'd to be at home.
10.29: But what most grated on my jealous mind,
10.30: Was that he there the waiting fool should find.
10.31: That aggravated most the cruel curse;
10.32: I would not wish my greatest foe a worse.
10.33: How oft have I attended you abroad,
10.34: Or in the city, cirque, or on the road ?
10.35: They took me for your husband by my care,
10.36: Or that your guardian or your slave I were.
10.37: I by the people's glances, and your own,
10.38: Observ'd you were acquainted with the town;
10.39: That of your love if I possess'd a part,
10.40: 'Twas plain I shared with many more your heart.
10.41: What need I of your perjuries bring proof,
10.42: Suppose the common talk was not enough!
10.43: What do your ogles and your gestures mean,
10.44: Your carriage at th' assembly and the scene ?
10.45: There's scarce a fop you meet with in your way,
10.46: To whom you have not something soft to say;
10.47: Some token which you either understand
10.48: By mystic words or motion of the hand.
10.49: They tell me you are sick; I run to see,
10.50: And find, as ill as you pretend to be,
10.51: It is not for my rival, but for me.
10.52: I seldom told you of your faults, but strove
10.53: To cover all your failings with my love;
10.54: Of this I might remind you, and much more,
10.55: But what avails it now; th' affair is o'er:
10.56: A fond you found me, and a patient man,
10.57: And get you such another if you can.
10.58: I fear not now your frowns; my bark defies
10.59: The storm of words, and tempest of your eyes;
10.60: No coaxing now, your hardest phrases use,
10.61: Your looks, your language, all their terrors lose;
10.62: I am not such a fool as I have been,
10.63: To dread your spirit, and to sooth your spleen.
10.64: But, ah! by diff'rent passions I'm oppress'd,
10.65: Fierce love and hate contend within my breast;
10.66: My soul they thus divide, but love, I fear,
10.67: Will prove too strong, and get the mast'ry there;
10.68: I'll strive to hate her, but if that should prove
10.69: A fruitless strife, in spite of me I'll love.
10.70: The bull does not affect the yoke, but still
10.71: He bears the thing he hates against his will
10.72: I hate, I fly the faithless fair in vain,
10.73: Her beauty ever brings me back again;
10.74: She always in my heart will have a place,
10.75: I hate her humour, but I love her face;
10.76: No rest I to my tortur'd soul can give,
10.77: Nor with her nor without her can I live.
10.78: Oh ! that thy mind we in thy face did view,
10.79: Less lovely that thou wert, or else more true.
10.80: How diffrent are thy manners and thy sight!
10.81: Thy deeds forbid us and thy eyes invite.
10.82: Thy actions shock us, and thy beauty moves,
10.83: And he who hates thy faults, thy person loves.
10.84: Happy, ah ! ever happy should I be,
10.85: If I no charms or no defects could see.
10.86: Thee I conjure by all our past delights,
10.87: Our cheerful days and our transporting nights,
10.88: By all the imprecated gods above,
10.89: To whom thou art forsworn, but most by Love,
10.90: By thy fair face, which I as much adore
10.91: As all those gods, and own as much its pow'r,
10.92: Forgive me this offence, and I'll offend no more.
10.93: Be what thou wilt, thy humour good or ill,
10.94: I'll love thee, thou shalt be my mistress still
10.95: Ah, let my passion ever favour find,
10.96: Or be it with, or be't against my mind,
10.97: But rather let me sail before the wind.
10.98: Ah, let thy wishes with my will agree,
10.99: Since surely I thy slave must ever be;
10.100: In thee since I have centred all my joys,
10.101: Oh Venus ! let my love be still my choice.

11.0: Ill-omen'd birds, how luckless was the day,
11.1: When o'er my love you did your wings display!
11.2: What wayward orb, what inauspicious star
11.3: Did then rule heav'n ? what gods against me war?
11.4: She who so much my fatal passion wrongs,
11.5: Was known and first made famous by my songs.
11.6: I lov'd her first, and lov'd her then alone,
11.7: But now, I fear, I share her with the town.
11.8: Am I deceiv'd or can she be the same,
11.9: Who only to my verses owes her fame
11.10: My verse a price upon her beauty laid,
11.11: And by my praises she her market made;
11.12: Whom but myself can I with reason blame?
11.13: Without me she had never had a name.
11.14: Did I do this, who knew her soul so well?
11.15: Dearly to me she did her favours sell;
11.16: And when the wares were to the public known,
11.17: Why should I think she'd sell to me alone ?
11.18: 'Twas I proclaim'd to all the town her charms,
11.19: And tempted cullies to her venal arms;
11.20: I made their way, I show'd them where to come,
11.21: And there is hardly now a rake in Rome
11.22: But knows her rates, and thanks my babbling muse:
11.23: Her house is now as common as the stews;
11.24: For this I'm to the muse oblig'd, and more
11.25: For all the mischiefs envy has in store.
11.26: This comes of gallantry, while some employ
11.27: Their talents on the fate of Thebes and Troy ,
11.28: While others Caesar's godlike acts rehearse,
11.29:
Corinna is the subject of my
						verse.
11.30: Oh, that I ne'er had known the art to please,
11.31: But written without genius and success.
11.32: Why did the town so readily believe
11.33: My verse, and why to songs such credit give ?
11.34: Sure poetry s the same it ever was,
11.35: And poets ne'er for oracles did pass.
11.36: Why is such stress upon my writings laid?
11.37: Why such regard to what by me is said ?
11.38:
I wish the tales I've of Corinna 
						told,
11.39: Had been receiv'd as fables were of old;
11.40: Of furious Scylla's horrid shape we read,
11.41: And how she scalp'd her hoary father's lead:
11.42: Of her fair face, and downward how she takes
11.43: The wolf's fierce form, the dog's, or curling snake's;
11.44: Serpents for hair, in ancient song we meet,
11.45: And man and horse with wings instead of feet.
11.46: Huge Tityon from the skies the poets flung,
11.47: Encelladus's wars with Jove they sung;
11.48: How by her spells, and by her voice, to beasts,
11.49: The doubtful virgin chang'd her wretched guests;
11.50: How Eolus did for Ulysses keep
11.51: The winds in bottles while he plough'd the deep:
11.52: How Cerberus, three headed, guarded hell;
11.53: And from his car the son of Phoebus fell:
11.54: How thirsty Tantalus attempts to sip
11.55: The stream in vain, that flies his greedy lip:
11.56: How Niobe in marble drops a tear,
11.57: And a bright nymph was turn'd into a bear:
11.58: How Progne, now a swallow, does bemoan
11.59: Her sister nightingale, and pheasant son.
11.60: In Leda, Danae, and Europa's rapes,
11.61: They sing the king of gods in various shapes;
11.62: A swan he lies on ravish'd Leda's breast,
11.63: And Danae by a golden show'r compress'd;
11.64: A bull does o'er the waves Europa bear,
11.65: And Proteus any form he pleases wear.
11.66: How oft do we the Theban wonders read,
11.67: Of serpent's teeth transform'd to human seed!
11.68: Of dancing woods, and moving rocks, that throng
11.69:
To hear sweet Orpheus, and Amphion 's
						song ?
11.70: How oft do the Heliades bemoan,
11.71: In tears of gum, the fall of Phaeton!
11.72: The sun from Atreus' table frightened flies,
11.73: And backward drives his chariot in the skies.
11.74: Those now are nymphs that lately were a fleet;
11.75: Poetic license ever was so great.
11.76: But none did credit to these fictions give,
11.77: Or for true history such tales receive,
11.78:
And though Corinna in my songs is
						fair,
11.79: Let none conclude she's like her picture there.
11.80: The fable she with hasty faith receiv'd,
11.81: And what, so very well she lik'd, believ'd.
11.82: But since so ill she does the poet use,

12.0: My wife, a native of Phaliscan plains,
12.1: Where the rich soils enrich the lab'ring swains,
12.2: Where purple grapes and golden apples grow,
12.3:
A conquest we to great Camillus 
						owe.
12.4:
When once to Juno 's feast she
						thither went,
12.5: My mind to know the secret rites was bent:
12.6: The pious priests the solemn sports prepare,
12.7: And purify the fane with holy care.
12.8: A heifer of the place they sacrifice,
12.9: But ne'er to men expose their mysteries,
12.10: I mark'd the hidden way my consort went,
12.11: And follow'd down the deep and dark descent.
12.12: To an old wood at last I came, whose shade
12.13: Impress'd a horror on the gloom it made,
12.14: And ev'ry step with trembling feet I trod,
12.15: Profan'd, I thought, the dwelling of a god.
12.16: An altar there was rais'd by hands divine,
12.17: And fragrant incense flam'd around the shrine.
12.18: Chaste matrons there their vow'd oblations pay,
12.19: And celebrate with joyful hymns the day.
12.20: Soon as the fife the signal gives, they move
12.21: In long procession through the sacred grove
12.22: Branches and flow'rs are with devotion spread
12.23: O'er all the way, and priestly vestments laid.
12.24: Next after these, through loud acclaims, they lead
12.25: A cow milk white, and of Phaliscan breed;
12.26: Then a young steer, whose forehead ne'er had borne
12.27: The crooked honours of the butting horn.
12.28: The least of all the victims was a swine,
12.29: And then a ram whose horns around his temples twine.
12.30: A goat, whom most the goddess hates, comes last;
12.31: The present feels her vengeance for the past.
12.32: When in a wood to hide herself she tried,
12.33: She by the bleating of a goat was spied;
12.34: For this the beast is by the boys pursu'd;
12.35: For this she's ever greedy of its blood,
12.36: And he, who first the letcher wounds in play,
12.37: Claims by her law, and hears the prize away.
12.38: The tender youth, and tim'rous virgin strow
12.39: With robes the ground the goddess is to go.
12.40: The virgins' locks with golden fillets bound,
12.41: And sparkling diamonds glitt'ring all around;
12.42: Buskins embroider'd on their feet they wear,
12.43: And spreading trains with pride uneasy bear.
12.44:
Here, as in Greece the custom was of
						old,
12.45: The image of the goddess we behold
12.46: Borne on the heads of maidens, and behind
12.47: The priestesses in beauteous rank you find.
12.48: An awful silence reigns : the goddess last
12.49: Approaches, and with her the pomp is past.
12.50: The dress was Greek, and such Halesus wore,
12.51: When in a fright he fled the Grecian shore;
12.52:
His father kill'd, an Argive ship he
						fraught,
12.53: And to this coast the royal treasure brought.
12.54: Much peril had he past, much labour known,
12.55: O'er lands and seas, before he reach'd our own,
12.56: And landing built, with happy hand, the town,
12.57: Where first he did this festival revive,
12.58: And its Greek rules to the Phaliscans give;
12.59: The rites and sacrifices first he show'd,
12.60: As practis'd now within this ancient wood.
12.61: Ah, may these rites to all propitious be,
12.62: No more to those that serv'd them than to me.

13.0: I do not ask you would to me prove true,
13.1: Since you're a woman, and a fair one too.
13.2: Act what you please, yet study to disguise
13.3: The wanton scenes from my deluded eyes.
13.5: That crime which your confession would make great.
13.6: And 'twere unwise to trust the tell-tale light,
13.7: With the dark secrets of the silent night.
13.8: Tho' bought to be enjoy'd, a common whore
13.9: Ere she begins will shut the chamber door:
13.10: And will you turn debauch'd, then vainly own
13.11: How lewd you are, to this malicious town?
13.12: At least seem virtuous, and tho' false you be,
13.13: Say you are honest, and I'll credit thee.
13.14: Conceal your actions, and while I am by,
13.15: Let modest words your looser thoughts belie;
13.16: When to your private chamber you retire,
13.17: Unmask your lust, and vent each warm desire;
13.18: Throw off affected coyness, and remove
13.19: The bold intruder between thee and love:
13.20: Talk not of honour, lay that toy aside,
13.21: In men 'tis folly, and in women pride;
13.22: There without blushes you may naked lie,
13.23: Clasping his body with your tender thigh;
13.24: Shoot your moist dart into his mouth, to show
13.25: The sense you have of what he acts below;
13.26: Try all the ways, your pliant bodies twine,
13.27: In folds more strange than those of Aretine:
13.28: With melting looks fierce joys you may excite,
13.29: And with thick dying accents urge delight.
13.30: But when you're dress'd, then look as innocent
13.31: As if you knew not what such matters meant;
13.32: Cozen the prying town, and put a cheat
13.33: On it and me, I'll favour the deceit.
13.34: False as thou art, why must I daily see
13.35: Th' intriguing billet-doux he sends to thee ?
13.36: The wanton sonnet, or soft elegy ?
13.37: Why does your bed all tumbled seem to say,
13.38: See what they've done, see where the lovers lay!
13.39: Why do your locks and rumpled head-clothes show
13.40: 'Tis more than usual sleep that made 'em so?
13.41: Why are the kisses which he gave, betray'd
13.42: By the impression which his teeth had made ?
13.43: Yet say you're chaste, and I'll be still deceived;
13.44: What much is wish'd for, is with ease believ'd.
13.45: But when you own what a lewd wretch thou art,
13.46: My blood grows cold and freezes at my heart,
13.47: Then do I curse thee, and thy crimes reprove,
13.48: But curse in vain, for still I find I love;
13.49: "Since she is false," oft to myself I cry,
13.50: "Would I were dead,"-yet 'tis with thee I'd die
13.51: I will not see your maid, to let me know
13.52: Who visits you, where, and with whom you go;
13.53: Nor by your lodging send my boy to scout,
13.54: And bring me word who passes in and out.
13.55: Enjoy the pleasure of the present times,
13.56: But let not me be knowing of your crimes.
13.57: Do you forswear't, tho' in the act you're caught,
13.58: I'll trust the oath, and think my eyes in fault.

14.0: To Virgil Mantua owes immortal fame,
14.1:
Catullus to Verona gives a
						name;
14.2: Why mayn't, if I attempt some great design,
14.3: Peligne be as much oblig'd to mine ?
14.4: Why mayn't my muse a glorious toil pursue,
14.5: And as much honour to my country do ?
14.6:
A people, who, when Rome has been
						alarm'd
14.7: By foreign foes, in her defence have arm'd;
14.8: Beneath your golden banners I have fought
14.9: So long, your discipline so much have taught,
14.10: 'Tis time to give me a discharge, to prove
14.11: Some other, some more glorious theme than love
14.12: See Bacchus beckons me my voice to raise,
14.13: Of lofty deeds to sings, in lofty lays;
14.14: To mount my muse on some more generous horse,
14.15: And try her courage in some daring course.
14.17: I'll be no more concern'd with love or you;
14.18: But what I write my being shall survive,
14.19: And in his verse the poet ever live.

edition: Ovid, 43 B.C.-17 or 18 A.D, creator; Dryden, John, 1631-1700, translator; Creech, Thomas, 1659-1700, translator; Hopkins, Charles, 1664?-1700?, translator; Duke, Richard, 1659?-1711, translator; Cromwell, Henry, 1659-1728, translator; Sedley, Charles, Sir, 1639-1701, translator; Eusden, Laurence, 1688-1730, translator; Rochester, John Wilmot, Earl of, 1647-1680, translator; Rymer, Thomas, 1641-1713, translator; Stepney, George, 1663-1707, translator; , editor
